translated: Does anyone who does not abandon the inherent tendency to lust for sensual desires and the inherent tendency to ill will not abandon the inherent tendency to lust for existence … the inherent tendency to conceit … the inherent tendency to false views … the inherent tendency to perplexity?🔽One who is possessed of the path of stream-entry does not abandon the inherent tendency to lust for sensual desires and the inherent tendency to ill will, but he does not abandon the inherent tendency to perplexity.

original: nappajahati. Dvinnaṁ maggasamaṅgīnaṁ ṭhapetvā avasesā puggalā kāmarāgānusayañca paṭighānusayañca
analyzed: na ppajahati dvinnam magga samaṅgīnam ṭhapetvā avasesā puggalā kāma rāga anusayañca paṭigha anusayañca
translated: Except for two who are possessed of the path, the remaining persons do not abandon the inherent tendency to lust for sensual desires and the inherent tendency to ill will

original: nappajahanti avijjānusayañca nappajahanti.
analyzed: na ppajahanti avijjā anusayam ca na ppajahanti
translated: and they do not abandon the inherent tendency to perplexity.

original: Yo vā pana avijjānusayaṁ nappajahati so kāmarāgānusayañca paṭighānusayañca nappajahatīti?
analyzed: yaḥ vā pana avijjā anusayam na ppajahati saḥ kāma rāga anusayam ca paṭigha anusayam ca na ppajahati iti
translated: But does anyone who does not abandon the inherent tendency to perplexity not abandon the inherent tendency to lust for sensual desires and the inherent tendency to ill will?

original: Anāgāmimaggasamaṅgī avijjānusayaṁ nappajahati, no ca so kāmarāgānusayañca paṭighānusayañca
analyzed: anāgāmi magga samaṅgī avijjā anusayam na ppajahati no ca so kāma rāga anusayam ca paṭigha anusayam ca
translated: One who is possessed of the path of non-return does not abandon the underlying tendency to ignorance, but he does not abandon the underlying tendency to lust for sensual desires and the underlying tendency to aversion.

original: nappajahati. Dvinnaṁ maggasamaṅgīnaṁ ṭhapetvā avasesā puggalā avijjānusayañca nappajahanti
analyzed: na ppajahati dvinnam magga samaṅgīnam ṭhapetvā avasesā puggalāḥ avijjā anusayam ca na ppajahanti
translated: Excepting two kinds of persons possessed of the path, the rest do not abandon the underlying tendency to ignorance

original: kāmarāgānusayañca paṭighānusayañca nappajahanti. (Dukamūlakaṁ.)
analyzed: kāma rāga anusayañca paṭigha anusayañca na ppajahanti duka mūlaka
translated: and they do not abandon the underlying tendency to lust for sensual desires and the underlying tendency to aversion. (The root of the triad.)

original: Yo kāmarāgānusayañca paṭighānusayañca mānānusayañca nappajahati so diṭṭhānusayaṁ …pe… vicikicchānusayaṁ nappajahatīti?🔽Aṭṭhamako kāmarāgānusayañca paṭighānusayañca mānānusayañca nappajahati, no ca so
analyzed: yaḥ kāma rāga anusayam ca paṭigha anusayam ca māna anusayam ca na pajahati saḥ diṭṭha anusayam pe vicikicchā anusayam na pajahati iti  aṭṭhamako kāma rāga anusayañca paṭigha anusayañca māna anusayañca na ppajahati no ca so
translated: Does anyone who does not abandon the underlying tendency to lust for sensual desires and the underlying tendency to aversion and the underlying tendency to conceit not abandon the underlying tendency to false view … the underlying tendency to uncertainty?🔽The eighth person does not abandon the underlying tendency to lust for sensual desires and the underlying tendency to aversion and the underlying tendency to conceit, but he does not abandon the underlying tendency to uncertainty.

original: vicikicchānusayaṁ nappajahati. Dvinnaṁ maggasamaṅgīnañca aṭṭhamakañca ṭhapetvā avasesā
analyzed: vicikicchā anusayam na ppajahati dvinnam magga samaṅgīnam ca aṭṭhamakam ca ṭhapetvā avasesā
translated: Excepting two kinds of persons possessed of the path and the eighth person, the rest

original: puggalā kāmarāgānusayañca paṭighānusayañca mānānusayañca nappajahanti vicikicchānusayañca nappajahanti.
analyzed: puggalā kāma rāga anusayañca paṭigha anusayañca māna anusayañca na ppajahanti vicikicchā anusayañca na ppajahanti
translated: do not abandon the underlying tendency to lust for sensual desires and the underlying tendency to aversion and the underlying tendency to conceit and they do not abandon the underlying tendency to uncertainty.

original: Yo vā pana vicikicchānusayaṁ nappajahati so kāmarāgānusayañca paṭighānusayañca mānānusayañca nappajahatīti?🔽Anāgāmimaggasamaṅgī vicikicchānusayañca mānānusayañca nappajahati, no ca so kāmarāgānusayañca🔽paṭighānusayañca nappajahati. Aggamaggasamaṅgī vicikicchānusayañca kāmarāgānusayañca
analyzed: yaḥ vā pana vicikicchā anusayam na ppajahati saḥ kāma rāga anusayam ca paṭigha anusayam ca māna anusayam ca na ppajahati iti  anāgāmi magga samaṅgī vicikicchā anusayañca māna anusayañca na ppajahati no ca so kāma rāga anusayañca  paṭigha anusayañca na ppajahati aggamagga samaṅgī vicikicchā anusayañca kāma rāga anusayañca
translated: Or does anyone who does not abandon the underlying tendency to uncertainty also not abandon the underlying tendency to lust for sensual desires, the underlying tendency to aversion, and the underlying tendency to conceit?

original: paṭighānusayañca nappajahati, no ca so mānānusayaṁ nappajahati. Dvinnaṁ maggasamaṅgīnañca
analyzed: paṭigha anusayam ca na ppajahati no ca so māna anusayam na ppajahati dvinnam magga samaṅgīnam ca
translated: One who possesses the path of non-return does not abandon the underlying tendency to uncertainty and the underlying tendency to conceit, but he does not not abandon the underlying tendency to lust for sensual desires and the underlying tendency to aversion. One who possesses the path of stream-entry does not abandon the underlying tendency to uncertainty, the underlying tendency to lust for sensual desires, and the underlying tendency to aversion, but he does not not abandon the underlying tendency to conceit.🔽Except for two persons who possess the path of non-return and the path of stream-entry,

original: aṭṭhamakañca ṭhapetvā avasesā puggalā vicikicchānusayañca nappajahanti kāmarāgānusayañca🔽paṭighānusayañca mānānusayañca nappajahanti.
analyzed: aṭṭhamakañca ṭhapetvā avasesā puggalā vicikicchā anusayañca na ppajahanti kāmarāga anusayañca  paṭigha anusayañca māna anusayañca na ppajahanti
translated: and the eighth person, the rest do not abandon the underlying tendency to uncertainty, and they do not abandon the underlying tendency to lust for sensual desires, the underlying tendency to aversion, and the underlying tendency to conceit.

original: Yo kāmarāgānusayañca paṭighānusayañca mānānusayañca nappajahati so bhavarāgānusayaṁ …pe… avijjānusayaṁ nappajahatīti? Āmantā.
analyzed: yaḥ kāma rāga anusayam ca paṭigha anusayam ca māna anusayam ca na pajahati saḥ bhava rāga anusayam pe avijjā anusayam na pajahati iti āmantā
translated: Or does anyone who does not abandon the underlying tendency to lust for sensual desires, the underlying tendency to aversion, and the underlying tendency to conceit also not abandon the underlying tendency to lust for existence, the underlying tendency to conceit, and the underlying tendency to ignorance?

original: Yo vā pana avijjānusayaṁ nappajahati so kāmarāgānusayañca paṭighānusayañca mānānusayañca nappajahatīti?🔽Anāgāmimaggasamaṅgī avijjānusayañca mānānusayañca nappajahati, no ca so kāmarāgānusayañca🔽paṭighānusayañca nappajahati. Dvinnaṁ maggasamaṅgīnaṁ ṭhapetvā avasesā puggalā avijjānusayañca
analyzed: yaḥ vā pana avijjā anusayam na ppajahati saḥ kāma rāga anusayam ca paṭigha anusayam ca māna anusayam ca na ppajahati iti  anāgāmi magga samaṅgī avijjā anusayañca māna anusayañca na ppajahati no ca so kāma rāga anusayañca  paṭigha anusayam ca na ppajahati dvinnam magga samaṅgīnam ṭhapetvā avasesā puggalāḥ avijjā anusayam ca
translated: Or does anyone who does not abandon the underlying tendency to ignorance not abandon the underlying tendency to lust for sensual desires, the underlying tendency to aversion, and the underlying tendency to conceit?🔽One who possesses the path of non-return does not abandon the underlying tendency to ignorance and the underlying tendency to conceit, but he does not not abandon the underlying tendency to lust for sensual desires and the underlying tendency to aversion.

original: nappajahanti kāmarāgānusayañca paṭighānusayañca mānānusayañca nappajahanti. (Tikamūlakaṁ.)🔽Yo kāmarāgānusayañca paṭighānusayañca mānānusayañca diṭṭhānusayañca nappajahati so vicikicchānusayaṁ nappajahatīti? Āmantā.
analyzed: na ppajahanti kāma rāga anusayañca paṭigha anusayañca māna anusayañca na ppajahanti tika mūlaka  yaḥ kāma rāga anusayam ca paṭigha anusayam ca māna anusayam ca diṭṭha anusayam ca na ppajahati saḥ vicikicchā anusayam na ppajahati iti āmantā
translated: Except for two persons who possess the path, the rest do not abandon the underlying tendency to ignorance and do not abandon the underlying tendency to lust for sensual desires, the underlying tendency to aversion, and the underlying tendency to conceit. (Threefold)🔽Does anyone who does not abandon the underlying tendency to lust for sensual desires, the underlying tendency to aversion, the underlying tendency to conceit, and the underlying tendency to views not abandon the underlying tendency to uncertainty?

original: Yo vā pana vicikicchānusayaṁ nappajahati so kāmarāgānusayañca paṭighānusayañca mānānusayañca diṭṭhānusayañca nappajahatīti?
analyzed: yaḥ vā pana vicikicchā anusayam na ppajahati saḥ kāma rāga anusayam ca paṭigha anusayam ca māna anusayam ca diṭṭha anusayam ca na ppajahati iti
translated: Or does anyone who does not abandon the underlying tendency to uncertainty not abandon the underlying tendency to lust for sensual desires, the underlying tendency to aversion, the underlying tendency to conceit, and the underlying tendency to views?

original: Anāgāmimaggasamaṅgī vicikicchānusayañca mānānusayañca diṭṭhānusayañca nappajahati,🔽no ca so kāmarāgānusayañca paṭighānusayañca nappajahati. Aggamaggasamaṅgī vicikicchānusayañca
analyzed: anāgāmi magga samaṅgī vicikicchā anusayañca māna anusayañca diṭṭha anusayañca na ppajahati  no ca so kāma rāga anusayañca paṭigha anusayañca na ppajahati aggamagga samaṅgī vicikicchā anusayañca
translated: One who is possessed of the path of non-return does not abandon the inherent tendency to uncertainty and the inherent tendency to conceit and the inherent tendency to views,

original: kāmarāgānusayañca paṭighānusayañca diṭṭhānusayañca nappajahati, no ca so mānānusayaṁ
analyzed: kāma rāga anusayañca paṭigha anusayañca diṭṭha anusayañca na ppajahati no ca so māna anusaya
translated: but he does not abandon the inherent tendency to lust and the inherent tendency to resentment. One who is possessed of the path of the highest fruit does not abandon the inherent tendency to uncertainty and the inherent tendency to lust and the inherent tendency to resentment and the inherent tendency to views,

original: nappajahati. Dvinnaṁ maggasamaṅgīnañca aṭṭhamakañca ṭhapetvā avasesā puggalā vicikicchānusayañca🔽nappajahanti kāmarāgānusayañca paṭighānusayañca mānānusayañca diṭṭhānusayañca nappajahanti
analyzed: na ppajahati dvinnam magga samaṅgīnam ca aṭṭhamakañca ṭhapetvā avasesā puggalāḥ vicikicchā anusayañca  na ppajahanti kāma rāga anusayañca paṭigha anusayañca māna anusayañca diṭṭha anusayañca na ppajahanti
translated: but he does not abandon the inherent tendency to conceit. Except for two possessed of the path and the eighth, the rest do not abandon the inherent tendency to uncertainty

original: …pe…. (Catukkamūlakaṁ.)
analyzed: pe
translated: and they do not abandon the inherent tendency to lust and the inherent tendency to resentment and the inherent tendency to conceit and the inherent tendency to views. … (Fourfold) …

original: Yo kāmarāgānusayañca paṭighānusayañca mānānusayañca diṭṭhānusayañca vicikicchānusayañca nappajahati so bhavarāgānusayaṁ …pe… avijjānusayaṁ nappajahatīti? Āmantā.
analyzed: yaḥ kāma rāga anusayam ca paṭigha anusayam ca māna anusayam ca diṭṭha anusayam ca vicikicchā anusayam ca na pajahati saḥ bhava rāga anusayam pe avijjā anusayam na pajahati iti āmantā
translated: One who does not abandon the inherent tendency to lust and the inherent tendency to resentment and the inherent tendency to conceit and the inherent tendency to views and the inherent tendency to uncertainty does not abandon the inherent tendency to desire for being … and the inherent tendency to ignorance? Yes.🔽…

original: Yo vā pana avijjānusayaṁ nappajahati so kāmarāgānusayañca paṭighānusayañca mānānusayañca diṭṭhānusayañca vicikicchānusayañca nappajahatīti?
analyzed: yaḥ vā pana avijjā anusayam na ppajahati saḥ kāma rāga anusayam ca paṭigha anusayam ca māna anusayam ca diṭṭha anusayam ca vicikicchā anusayam ca na ppajahati iti
translated: Or does anyone who does not abandon the underlying tendency to ignorance not abandon the underlying tendency to lust for sensual desires, the underlying tendency to aversion, the underlying tendency to conceit, the underlying tendency to views, and the underlying tendency to doubt?

original: Aṭṭhamako avijjānusayañca kāmarāgānusayañca paṭighānusayañca mānānusayañca nappajahati,
analyzed: aṭṭhamakaḥ avijjā anusayañca kāma rāga anusayañca paṭigha anusayañca māna anusayañca na ppajahati
translated: One on the eighth path does not abandon the underlying tendency to ignorance and the underlying tendency to conceit,

original: no ca so diṭṭhānusayañca vicikicchānusayañca nappajahati. Anāgāmimaggasamaṅgī avijjānusayañca🔽mānānusayañca diṭṭhānusayañca vicikicchānusayañca nappajahati, no ca so kāmarāgānusayañca
analyzed: no ca so diṭṭha anusayañca vicikicchā anusayañca na ppajahati anāgāmi magga samaṅgī avijjā anusayañca  māna anusayañca diṭṭha anusayañca vicikicchā anusayañca na ppajahati no ca so kāma rāga anusayañca
translated: but he does not abandon the underlying tendency to views and the underlying tendency to doubt. One possessing the non-return path does not abandon the underlying tendency to ignorance and the underlying tendency to conceit and the underlying tendency to views and the underlying tendency to doubt,

original: paṭighānusayañca nappajahati. Dvinnaṁ maggasamaṅgīnañca aṭṭhamakañca ṭhapetvā avasesā🔽puggalā avijjānusayañca nappajahanti kāmarāgānusayañca paṭighānusayañca mānānusayañca
analyzed: paṭigha anusayañca na ppajahati dvinnam magga samaṅgīnam ca aṭṭhamakañca ṭhapetvā avasesā  puggalāḥ avijjā anusayañca na ppajahanti kāma rāga anusayañca paṭigha anusayañca māna anusayañca
translated: but he does not abandon the underlying tendency to lust for sensual desires and the underlying tendency to aversion. Except for those possessing two paths and one on the eighth path,

original: diṭṭhānusayañca vicikicchānusayañca nappajahanti. (Pañcakamūlakaṁ.)
analyzed: diṭṭha anusayañca vicikicchā anusayañca na ppajahanti pañcaka mūlaka
translated: the remaining persons do not abandon the underlying tendency to ignorance and do not abandon the underlying tendency to lust for sensual desires and the underlying tendency to aversion and the underlying tendency to conceit and the underlying tendency to views and the underlying tendency to doubt. (Fivefold root.)

original: Yo kāmarāgānusayañca paṭighānusayañca mānānusayañca diṭṭhānusayañca vicikicchānusayañca bhavarāgānusayañca nappajahati so avijjānusayaṁ nappajahatīti? Āmantā.
analyzed: yaḥ kāma rāga anusayam ca paṭigha anusayam ca māna anusayam ca diṭṭha anusayam ca vicikicchā anusayam ca bhava rāga anusayañca na ppajahati saḥ avijjā anusayam na ppajahati iti āmantā
translated: Does he who does not abandon the underlying tendency to lust for sensual pleasure, the underlying tendency to aversion, the underlying tendency to conceit, the underlying tendency to views, the underlying tendency to uncertainty, the underlying tendency to lust for existence, not abandon the underlying tendency to ignorance?

original: Yo vā pana avijjānusayaṁ nappajahati so kāmarāgānusayañca paṭighānusayañca mānānusayañca diṭṭhānusayañca vicikicchānusayañca bhavarāgānusayañca nappajahatīti?
analyzed: yaḥ vā pana avijjā anusayam na ppajahati saḥ kāma rāga anusayam ca paṭigha anusayam ca māna anusayam ca diṭṭha anusayam ca vicikicchā anusayam ca bhava rāga anusayañca na ppajahati iti
translated: Or does he who abandons the underlying tendency to ignorance abandon the underlying tendency to lust for sensual pleasure … the underlying tendency to lust for existence?

original: Aṭṭhamako avijjānusayañca kāmarāgānusayañca paṭighānusayañca mānānusayañca bhavarāgānusayañca
analyzed: aṭṭhamakaḥ avijjā anusayañca kāma rāga anusayañca paṭigha anusayañca māna anusayañca bhava rāga anusayañca
translated: One in the eighth who does not abandon the underlying tendency to ignorance, the underlying tendency to lust for sensual pleasure, the underlying tendency to aversion, the underlying tendency to conceit, the underlying tendency to lust for existence,

original: nappajahati, no ca so diṭṭhānusayañca vicikicchānusayañca nappajahati. Anāgāmimaggasamaṅgī
analyzed: na ppajahati no ca so diṭṭha anusayañca vicikicchā anusayañca na ppajahati anāgāmi magga samaṅgī
translated: but does not abandon the underlying tendency to views and the underlying tendency to uncertainty. One possessing the path of non-return

original: avijjānusayañca mānānusayañca diṭṭhānusayañca vicikicchānusayañca bhavarāgānusayañca
analyzed: avijjā anusayañca māna anusayañca diṭṭha anusayañca vicikicchā anusayañca bhava rāga anusayañca
translated: who does not abandon the underlying tendency to ignorance, the underlying tendency to conceit, the underlying tendency to views, the underlying tendency to uncertainty, the underlying tendency to lust for existence,

original: nappajahati, no ca so kāmarāgānusayañca paṭighānusayañca nappajahati. Dvinnaṁ maggasamaṅgīnañca
analyzed: na ppajahati no ca so kāma rāga anusayam ca paṭigha anusayam ca na ppajahati dvinnam magga samaṅgīnam ca
translated: but does not abandon the underlying tendency to lust for sensual pleasure and the underlying tendency to aversion. Two possessing the path

original: aṭṭhamakañca ṭhapetvā avasesā puggalā avijjānusayañca nappajahanti kāmarāgānusayañca
analyzed: aṭṭhamakañca ṭhapetvā avasesā puggalā avijjā anusayañca na ppajahanti kāma rāga anusayañca
translated: except for the eighth person, the rest do not abandon the underlying tendency to ignorance and the underlying tendency to lust for sensual pleasures

original: paṭighānusayañca mānānusayañca diṭṭhānusayañca vicikicchānusayañca bhavarāgānusayañca
analyzed: paṭigha anusayañca māna anusayañca diṭṭha anusayañca vicikicchā anusayañca bhava rāga anusayañca
translated: and the underlying tendency to aversion and the underlying tendency to conceit and the underlying tendency to views and the underlying tendency to uncertainty and the underlying tendency to lust for existence.

original: nappajahanti. (Chakkamūlakaṁ.)
analyzed: na ppajahanti chakkamūlaka
translated: (The wheel of the six pairs.)

original: 7.2.3.5. Paṭilomaokāsa
analyzed: paṭiloma okāsa
translated: ... The reverse order

original: Yato kāmarāgānusayaṁ nappajahati tato paṭighānusayaṁ nappajahatīti?🔽Dukkhāya vedanāya tato kāmarāgānusayaṁ nappajahati, no ca tato paṭighānusayaṁ nappajahati.
analyzed: yatas kāma rāga anusayam na ppajahati tatas paṭigha anusayam na ppajahati iti  dukkhāya vedanāya tato kāma rāga anusayam na ppajahati no ca tato paṭigha anusayam na ppajahati
translated: From the time that he does not abandon the underlying tendency to lust for sensual pleasures, does he not abandon the underlying tendency to aversion?🔽In painful feeling, from that time he does not abandon the underlying tendency to lust for sensual pleasures but he does not not abandon the underlying tendency to aversion.

original: Rūpadhātuyā arūpadhātuyā apariyāpanne tato kāmarāgānusayañca nappajahati paṭighānusayañca nappajahati.
analyzed: rūpa dhātuyā a rūpa dhātuyā apariyāpanne tatas kāma rāga anusayam ca na pajahati paṭigha anusayam ca na pajahati
translated: In the fine-material and immaterial dhammas, and in the unincluded dhammas, he does not abandon the underlying tendency to lust for sensual pleasures and he does not abandon the underlying tendency to aversion.

original: Yato vā pana paṭighānusayaṁ nappajahati tato kāmarāgānusayaṁ nappajahatīti?
analyzed: yatas vā pana paṭigha anusayam na ppajahati tatas kāma rāga anusayam na ppajahati iti
translated: But from the time that he does not abandon the underlying tendency to aversion, does he not abandon the underlying tendency to lust for sensual pleasures?

original: Kāmadhātuyā dvīsu vedanāsu tato paṭighānusayaṁ nappajahati, no ca tato kāmarāgānusayaṁ
analyzed: kāmadhātuyā dvīsu vedanāsu tato paṭigha anusayam na ppajahati no ca tato kāma rāga anusaya
translated: In the two kinds of feeling in the sense-desire element, from that time he does not abandon the underlying tendency to aversion but he does not not abandon the underlying tendency to lust for sensual pleasures.

original: nappajahati. Rūpadhātuyā arūpadhātuyā apariyāpanne tato paṭighānusayañca nappajahati
analyzed: na ppajahati rūpa dhātuyā a rūpa dhātuyā a pariyāpanne tatas paṭigha anusayam ca na ppajahati
translated: he does not abandon the underlying tendency to resistance.

original: kāmarāgānusayañca nappajahati.
analyzed: kāma rāga anusayam ca na appajahati
translated: he does not abandon the underlying tendency to lust for sensual desires.

original: Yato kāmarāgānusayaṁ nappajahati tato mānānusayaṁ nappajahatīti?🔽Rūpadhātuyā arūpadhātuyā tato kāmarāgānusayaṁ nappajahati, no ca tato mānānusayaṁ
analyzed: yatas kāma rāga anusayam na ppajahati tatas māna anusayam na ppajahati iti  rūpa dhātuyā arūpa dhātuyā tato kāma rāga anusayam na ppajahati no ca tato māna anusaya
translated: When he does not abandon the underlying tendency to lust for sensual desires, does he then not abandon the underlying tendency to conceit?🔽When he does not abandon the underlying tendency to lust for sensual desires, he does not abandon the underlying tendency to conceit in the fine-material and immaterial dhammas.

original: nappajahati. Dukkhāya vedanāya apariyāpanne tato kāmarāgānusayañca nappajahati mānānusayañca nappajahati.
analyzed: na ppajahati dukkhāya vedanāya apariyāpanne tatas kāma rāga anusayañca na ppajahati māna anusayañca na ppajahati
translated: But he does not abandon the underlying tendency to conceit in the painful feeling and in the dhammas not included in the three kinds of feeling.

original: Yato vā pana mānānusayaṁ nappajahati tato kāmarāgānusayaṁ nappajahatīti? Āmantā.
analyzed: yatas vā pana māna anusayam na pajahati tatas kāma rāga anusayam na ppajahati iti āmantā
translated: When he does not abandon the underlying tendency to conceit, does he then not abandon the underlying tendency to lust for sensual desires?

original: Yato kāmarāgānusayaṁ nappajahati tato diṭṭhānusayaṁ …pe… vicikicchānusayaṁ nappajahatīti?
analyzed: yatas kāma rāga anusayam na pajahati tatas diṭṭha anusayam pe vicikicchā anusayam na pajahati iti
translated: When he does not abandon the underlying tendency to lust for sensual desires, does he then not abandon the underlying tendency to the false view of existence … the underlying tendency to the false view of sensual enjoyment … the underlying tendency to conceit … the underlying tendency to the insistence on rules and vows … the underlying tendency to doubt?

original: Dukkhāya vedanāya rūpadhātuyā arūpadhātuyā tato kāmarāgānusayaṁ nappajahati, no ca
analyzed: dukkhāya vedanāya rūpa dhātuyā arūpa dhātuyā tatas kāma rāga anusayam na ppajahati no ca
translated: When he does not abandon the underlying tendency to lust for sensual desires, he does not abandon the underlying tendency to doubt in the painful feeling and in the fine-material and immaterial dhammas.

original: tato vicikicchānusayaṁ nappajahati. Apariyāpanne tato kāmarāgānusayañca nappajahati
analyzed: tatas vicikicchā anusayam na ppajahati apariyāpanne tatas kāma rāga anusayañca na ppajahati
translated: but he does not abandon the underlying tendency to scepticism. In the incorporeal form element he does not abandon the underlying tendency to lust,

original: vicikicchānusayañca nappajahati.
analyzed: vicikicchā anusayam ca na appajahati
translated: but he does not abandon the underlying tendency to scepticism.

original: Yato vā pana vicikicchānusayaṁ nappajahati tato kāmarāgānusayaṁ nappajahatīti? Āmantā.
analyzed: yatas vā pana vicikicchā anusayam na ppajahati tatas kāma rāga anusayam na ppajahati iti āmantā
translated: Or alternatively, when he does not abandon the underlying tendency to scepticism, does he not abandon the underlying tendency to lust?

original: Yato kāmarāgānusayaṁ nappajahati tato bhavarāgānusayaṁ nappajahatīti?🔽Rūpadhātuyā arūpadhātuyā tato kāmarāgānusayaṁ nappajahati, no ca tato bhavarāgānusayaṁ
analyzed: yatas kāma rāga anusayam na ppajahati tatas bhava rāga anusayam na ppajahati iti  rūpa dhātuyā arūpa dhātuyā tato kāma rāga anusayam na ppajahati no ca tato bhava rāga anusaya
translated: When he does not abandon the underlying tendency to lust, does he not abandon the underlying tendency to conceit?🔽In the fine-material and immaterial form elements he does not abandon the underlying tendency to lust,🔽but he does not abandon the underlying tendency to conceit. In the painful feeling and in the incorporeal form element he does not abandon the underlying tendency to lust,

original: nappajahati. Dukkhāya vedanāya apariyāpanne tato kāmarāgānusayañca nappajahati bhavarāgānusayañca nappajahati.
analyzed: na ppajahati dukkhāya vedanāya apariyāpanne tatas kāma rāga anusayañca na ppajahati bhava rāga anusayañca na ppajahati
translated: but he does not abandon the underlying tendency to conceit.

original: Yato vā pana bhavarāgānusayaṁ nappajahati tato kāmarāgānusayaṁ nappajahatīti?
analyzed: yatas vā pana bhava rāga anusayam na ppajahati tatas kāma rāga anusayam na ppajahati iti
translated: Or alternatively, when he does not abandon the underlying tendency to conceit, does he not abandon the underlying tendency to lust?🔽In the two kinds of feeling in the sensual-desire element he does not abandon the underlying tendency to conceit,

original: Kāmadhātuyā dvīsu vedanāsu tato bhavarāgānusayaṁ nappajahati, no ca tato kāmarāgānusayaṁ
analyzed: kāmadhātuyā dvīsu vedanāsu tatas bhava rāga anusayam na ppajahati no ca tatas kāma rāga anusaya
translated: but he does not abandon the underlying tendency to lust.

original: nappajahati. Dukkhāya vedanāya apariyāpanne tato bhavarāgānusayañca nappajahati kāmarāgānusayañca nappajahati.
analyzed: na ppajahati dukkhāya vedanāya apariyāpanne tatas bhava rāga anusayam ca na ppajahati kāma rāga anusayam ca na ppajahati
translated: he does not abandon the underlying tendency to lust. In the case of painful feeling that is not included in the three above-mentioned planes, he does not abandon the underlying tendency to lust and he does not abandon the underlying tendency to conceit.

original: Yato kāmarāgānusayaṁ nappajahati tato avijjānusayaṁ nappajahatīti?🔽Dukkhāya vedanāya rūpadhātuyā arūpadhātuyā tato kāmarāgānusayaṁ nappajahati, no ca
analyzed: yatas kāma rāga anusayam na ppajahati tatas avijjā anusayam na ppajahati iti  dukkhāya vedanāya rūpa dhātuyā arūpa dhātuyā tatas kāma rāga anusayam na ppajahati no ca
translated: When he does not abandon the underlying tendency to lust, does he then not abandon the underlying tendency to ignorance?

original: tato avijjānusayaṁ nappajahati. Apariyāpanne tato kāmarāgānusayañca nappajahati avijjānusayañca nappajahati.
analyzed: tatas avijjā anusayam nappajahati apariyāpanne tatas kāma rāga anusayam ca nappajahati avijjā anusayam ca nappajahati
translated: In the case of painful feeling in the fine-material and immaterial dhammas, he does not abandon the underlying tendency to lust but he does not abandon the underlying tendency to ignorance. original: Yato vā pana avijjānusayaṁ nappajahati tato kāmarāgānusayaṁ nappajahatīti? Āmantā.
