analyzed: rūpa dhātuyā arūpa dhātuyā tatas kāma rāga anusayañca paṭigha anusayañca na ppajahati no  ca tatas māna anusayam na pajahati apariyāpanne tatas kāma rāga anusayam ca paṭigha anusayam ca
translated: In the fine-material and immaterial dhammas he does not abandon the underlying tendency to lust for existence and the underlying tendency to resentment,

original: nappajahati mānānusayañca nappajahati.
analyzed: na ppajahati māna anusayam ca na ppajahati
translated: but he does not abandon the underlying tendency to conceit. In the inconstant he does not abandon the underlying tendency to lust for existence and the underlying tendency to resentment nor the underlying tendency to conceit.

original: Yato vā pana mānānusayaṁ nappajahati tato kāmarāgānusayañca paṭighānusayañca nappajahatīti?
analyzed: yatas vā pana māna anusayam na pajahati tatas kāma rāga anusayam ca paṭigha anusayam ca na ppajahati iti
translated: Or alternatively, where he does not abandon the underlying tendency to conceit, does he not abandon the underlying tendency to lust for existence and the underlying tendency to resentment there?

original: Dukkhāya vedanāya tato mānānusayañca kāmarāgānusayañca nappajahati, no ca tato paṭighānusayaṁ
analyzed: dukkhāya vedanāya tatas māna anusayañca kāma rāga anusayañca na ppajahati no ca tatas paṭigha anusaya
translated: He does not abandon the underlying tendency to conceit and the underlying tendency to lust for sensual pleasure in regard to painful feeling, but he does abandon the underlying tendency to resentment.

original: nappajahati. Apariyāpanne tato mānānusayañca nappajahati kāmarāgānusayañca paṭighānusayañca nappajahati.🔽Yato kāmarāgānusayañca paṭighānusayañca nappajahati tato diṭṭhānusayaṁ …pe… vicikicchānusayaṁ nappajahatīti?🔽Rūpadhātuyā arūpadhātuyā tato kāmarāgānusayañca paṭighānusayañca nappajahati, no
analyzed: na pajahati a pariyāpanne tatas māna anusayañca na ppajahati kāma rāga anusayañca paṭigha anusayañca na ppajahati  yatas kāma rāga anusayam ca paṭigha anusayam ca na ppajahati tatas diṭṭha anusayam pe vicikicchā anusayam na ppajahati iti  rūpa dhātuyā arūpa dhātuyā tatas kāma rāga anusayañca paṭigha anusayañca na ppajahati no
translated: He does not abandon the underlying tendency to conceit in regard to the imperturbable, but he does abandon the underlying tendency to lust for sensual pleasure and the underlying tendency to resentment.🔽“When he does not abandon the underlying tendency to lust for sensual pleasure and the underlying tendency to resentment, does he then not abandon the underlying tendency to views? … the underlying tendency to conceit? … the underlying tendency to lust for existence? … the underlying tendency to conceit? … the underlying tendency to ignorance?”

original: ca tato vicikicchānusayaṁ nappajahati. Apariyāpanne tato kāmarāgānusayañca paṭighānusayañca🔽nappajahati vicikicchānusayañca nappajahati.
analyzed: ca tatas vicikicchā anusayam na ppajahati apariyāpanne tatas kāma rāga anusayam ca paṭigha anusayam ca  na ppajahati vicikicchā anusayam ca na ppajahati
translated: He does not abandon the underlying tendency to lust for sensual pleasure and the underlying tendency to resentment in regard to the fine-material and immaterial dhammas, but he does abandon the underlying tendency to ignorance.🔽He does not abandon the underlying tendency to lust for sensual pleasure and the underlying tendency to resentment in regard to the imperturbable, but he does abandon the underlying tendency to ignorance.

original: Yato vā pana vicikicchānusayaṁ nappajahati tato kāmarāgānusayañca paṭighānusayañca nappajahatīti? Āmantā.
analyzed: yatas vā pana vicikicchā anusayam na pajahati tatas kāma rāga anusayam ca paṭigha anusayam ca na pajahati iti āmantā
translated: “When he does not abandon the underlying tendency to ignorance, does he then not abandon the underlying tendency to lust for sensual pleasure and the underlying tendency to resentment?”

original: Yato kāmarāgānusayañca paṭighānusayañca nappajahati tato bhavarāgānusayaṁ nappajahatīti?🔽Rūpadhātuyā arūpadhātuyā tato kāmarāgānusayañca paṭighānusayañca nappajahati, no
analyzed: yatas kāma rāga anusayam ca paṭigha anusayam ca na ppajahati tatas bhava rāga anusayam na ppajahati iti  rūpa dhātuyā arūpa dhātuyā tatas kāma rāga anusayañca paṭigha anusayañca na ppajahati no
translated: When he does not abandon the underlying tendency to lust for sensual desires and the underlying tendency to aversion, does he then not abandon the underlying tendency to lust for existence?🔽When he does not abandon the underlying tendency to lust for sensual desires and the underlying tendency to aversion in the fine-material and immaterial dhammas,

original: ca tato bhavarāgānusayaṁ nappajahati. Apariyāpanne tato kāmarāgānusayañca paṭighānusayañca
analyzed: ca tatas bhava rāga anusayam na pajahati apariyāpanne tatas kāma rāga anusayam ca paṭigha anusayam ca
translated: he does not abandon the underlying tendency to lust for existence there. When he does not abandon the underlying tendency to lust for sensual desires and the underlying tendency to aversion in the unincluded dhammas,

original: nappajahati bhavarāgānusayañca nappajahati.
analyzed: na ppajahati bhava rāga anusayam ca na ppajahati
translated: he does not abandon the underlying tendency to lust for existence there.

original: Yato vā pana bhavarāgānusayaṁ nappajahati tato kāmarāgānusayañca paṭighānusayañca nappajahatīti?🔽Dukkhāya vedanāya tato bhavarāgānusayañca kāmarāgānusayañca nappajahati, no ca tato🔽paṭighānusayaṁ nappajahati. Kāmadhātuyā dvīsu vedanāsu tato bhavarāgānusayañca paṭighānusayañca
analyzed: yatas vā pana bhava rāga anusayam na pajahati tatas kāma rāga anusayam ca paṭigha anusayam ca na ppajahati iti  dukkhāya vedanāya tatas bhava rāga anusayañca kāma rāga anusayañca na ppajahati no ca tatas  paṭigha anusayam na pajahati kāmadhātuyā dvīsu vedanāsu tatas bhava rāga anusayam ca paṭigha anusayam ca
translated: Or when he does not abandon the underlying tendency to lust for existence, does he then not abandon the underlying tendency to lust for sensual desires and the underlying tendency to aversion?🔽When he does not abandon the underlying tendency to lust for existence and the underlying tendency to lust for sensual desires in painful feeling, he does not abandon the underlying tendency to aversion there. When he does not abandon the underlying tendency to lust for existence and the underlying tendency to aversion in the two kinds of feeling in the sensual-desire element,

original: nappajahati, no ca tato kāmarāgānusayaṁ nappajahati. Apariyāpanne tato bhavarāgānusayañca
analyzed: na ppajahati no ca tatas kāma rāga anusayam na ppajahati apariyāpanne tatas bhava rāga anusayam ca
translated: he does not abandon the underlying tendency to lust for sensual desires there. When he does not abandon the underlying tendency to lust for existence and the underlying tendency to aversion in the unincluded dhammas,🔽he does not abandon the underlying tendency to lust for sensual desires there.

original: nappajahati kāmarāgānusayañca paṭighānusayañca nappajahati.
analyzed: na ppajahati kāma rāga anusayañca paṭigha anusayañca na ppajahati
translated: he does not abandon the underlying tendency to lust and the underlying tendency to aversion.

original: Yato kāmarāgānusayañca paṭighānusayañca nappajahati tato avijjānusayaṁ nappajahatīti?
analyzed: yatas kāma rāga anusayam ca paṭigha anusayam ca na ppajahati tatas avijjā anusayam na ppajahati iti
translated: “When he does not abandon the underlying tendency to lust and the underlying tendency to aversion, does he then not abandon the underlying tendency to ignorance?”

original: Rūpadhātuyā arūpadhātuyā tato kāmarāgānusayañca paṭighānusayañca nappajahati, no🔽ca tato avijjānusayaṁ nappajahati. Apariyāpanne tato kāmarāgānusayañca paṭighānusayañca
analyzed: rūpa dhātuyā arūpa dhātuyā tatas kāma rāga anusayañca paṭigha anusayañca na ppajahati no  ca tatas avijjā anusayam na ppajahati apariyāpanne tatas kāma rāga anusayam ca paṭigha anusayam ca
translated: In the case of the fine-material and immaterial dhammas, he does not abandon the underlying tendency to lust and the underlying tendency to aversion,

original: nappajahati avijjānusayañca nappajahati.🔽Yato vā pana avijjānusayaṁ nappajahati tato kāmarāgānusayañca paṭighānusayañca nappajahatīti? Āmantā. (Dukamūlakaṁ.)
analyzed: na ppajahati avijjā anusayam ca na ppajahati  yatas vā pana avijjā anusayam na pajahati tatas kāma rāga anusayam ca paṭigha anusayam ca na ppajahati iti āmantā dukamūlaka
translated: but he does not abandon the underlying tendency to ignorance.🔽In the case of the dhammas not included in the three planes, he does not abandon the underlying tendency to lust and the underlying tendency to aversion and the underlying tendency to ignorance.🔽“When he does not abandon the underlying tendency to ignorance, does he then not abandon the underlying tendency to lust and the underlying tendency to aversion?”🔽“When he does not abandon the underlying tendency to lust and the underlying tendency to aversion and the underlying tendency to conceit, does he then not abandon the underlying tendency to views … the underlying tendency to doubt?”

original: Yato kāmarāgānusayañca paṭighānusayañca mānānusayañca nappajahati tato diṭṭhānusayaṁ …pe… vicikicchānusayaṁ nappajahatīti? Āmantā.
analyzed: yatas kāma rāga anusayam ca paṭigha anusayam ca māna anusayam ca na pajahati tatas diṭṭha anusayam pe vicikicchā anusayam na pajahati iti āmantā
translated: “When he does not abandon the underlying tendency to lust and the underlying tendency to aversion and the underlying tendency to conceit and the underlying tendency to views, does he then not abandon the underlying tendency to ignorance?”

original: Yato vā pana vicikicchānusayaṁ nappajahati tato kāmarāgānusayañca paṭighānusayañca mānānusayañca nappajahatīti? Āmantā.
analyzed: yatas vā pana vicikicchā anusayam na pajahati tatas kāma rāga anusayam ca paṭigha anusayam ca māna anusayam ca na ppajahati iti āmantā
translated: Or from not abandoning the underlying tendency to uncertainty does he not abandon the underlying tendency to lust for sensual desires, the underlying tendency to resentment, and the underlying tendency to conceit?

original: Yato kāmarāgānusayañca paṭighānusayañca mānānusayañca nappajahati tato bhavarāgānusayaṁ nappajahatīti? Āmantā.
analyzed: yatas kāma rāga anusayam ca paṭigha anusayam ca māna anusayam ca na ppajahati tatas bhava rāga anusayam na ppajahati iti āmantā
translated: From not abandoning the underlying tendency to lust for sensual desires, the underlying tendency to resentment, and the underlying tendency to conceit does he not abandon the underlying tendency to lust for existence?

original: Yato vā pana bhavarāgānusayaṁ nappajahati tato kāmarāgānusayañca paṭighānusayañca mānānusayañca nappajahatīti?
analyzed: yatas vā pana bhava rāga anusayam na pajahati tatas kāma rāga anusayam ca paṭigha anusayam ca māna anusayam ca na ppajahati iti
translated: Or from not abandoning the underlying tendency to lust for existence does he not abandon the underlying tendency to lust for sensual desires, the underlying tendency to resentment, and the underlying tendency to conceit?

original: Dukkhāya vedanāya tato bhavarāgānusayañca kāmarāgānusayañca mānānusayañca nappajahati,
analyzed: dukkhāya vedanāya tatas bhava rāga anusayañca kāma rāga anusayañca māna anusayañca na ppajahati
translated: In painful feeling he does not abandon the underlying tendency to lust for existence, the underlying tendency to lust for sensual desires, and the underlying tendency to conceit,🔽but he does not abandon the underlying tendency to resentment. In the two kinds of feeling in the fine-material and immaterial kinds of becoming he does not abandon the underlying tendency to lust for existence and the underlying tendency to resentment,

original: no ca tato paṭighānusayaṁ nappajahati. Kāmadhātuyā dvīsu vedanāsu tato bhavarāgānusayañca
analyzed: no ca tatas paṭigha anusayam na ppajahati kāmadhātuyā dvīsu vedanāsu tatas bhava rāga anusayam ca
translated: but he does not abandon the underlying tendency to lust for sensual desires and the underlying tendency to conceit.🔽In the imperturbable he does not abandon the underlying tendency to lust for existence,

original: paṭighānusayañca nappajahati, no ca tato kāmarāgānusayañca mānānusayañca nappajahati.🔽Apariyāpanne tato bhavarāgānusayañca nappajahati kāmarāgānusayañca paṭighānusayañca
analyzed: paṭigha anusayañca na ppajahati no ca tatas kāma rāga anusayañca māna anusayañca na ppajahati 🔽apariyāpanne tatas bhava rāga anusayañca na ppajahati kāma rāga anusayañca paṭigha anusayañca
translated: but he does not abandon the underlying tendency to lust for sensual desires and the underlying tendency to resentment.

original: mānānusayañca nappajahati.🔽Yato kāmarāgānusayañca paṭighānusayañca mānānusayañca nappajahati tato avijjānusayaṁ nappajahatīti? Āmantā.
analyzed: māna anusayam ca na appajahati  yatas kāma rāga anusayam ca paṭigha anusayam ca māna anusayam ca na pajahati tatas avijjā anusayam na pajahati iti āmantā
translated: and he does not abandon the underlying tendency to conceit.🔽“When he does not abandon the underlying tendency to lust, the underlying tendency to aversion, and the underlying tendency to conceit, does he then not abandon the underlying tendency to ignorance?” “He does not.”

original: Yato vā pana avijjānusayaṁ nappajahati tato kāmarāgānusayañca paṭighānusayañca mānānusayañca nappajahatīti? Āmantā. (Tikamūlakaṁ.)🔽Yato kāmarāgānusayañca paṭighānusayañca mānānusayañca diṭṭhānusayañca nappajahati tato vicikicchānusayaṁ nappajahatīti? Āmantā.🔽Yato vā pana vicikicchānusayaṁ nappajahati tato kāmarāgānusayañca paṭighānusayañca mānānusayañca diṭṭhānusayañca nappajahatīti? Āmantā …pe…. (Catukkamūlakaṁ.)
analyzed: yatas vā pana avijjā anusayam na pajahati tatas kāma rāga anusayam ca paṭigha anusayam ca māna anusayam ca na ppajahati iti āmantā tikamūlaka  yatas kāma rāga anusayam ca paṭigha anusayam ca māna anusayam ca diṭṭha anusayam ca na ppajahati tatas vicikicchā anusayam na ppajahati iti āmantā  yatas vā pana vicikicchā anusayam na pajahati tatas kāma rāga anusayam ca paṭigha anusayam ca māna anusayam ca diṭṭha anusayam ca na pajahati iti āmantā pe catukkamūlaka
translated: “When he does not abandon the underlying tendency to ignorance, does he then not abandon the underlying tendency to lust, the underlying tendency to aversion, and the underlying tendency to conceit?” “He does not.”🔽“When he does not abandon the underlying tendency to lust, the underlying tendency to aversion, the underlying tendency to conceit, and the underlying tendency to views, does he then not abandon the underlying tendency to doubt?” “He does not.”🔽“When he does not abandon the underlying tendency to doubt, does he then not abandon the underlying tendency to lust, the underlying tendency to aversion, the underlying tendency to conceit, and the underlying tendency to views?” “He does not.”

original: Yato kāmarāgānusayañca paṭighānusayañca mānānusayañca diṭṭhānusayañca vicikicchānusayañca nappajahati tato bhavarāgānusayaṁ nappajahatīti? Āmantā.
analyzed: yatas kāma rāga anusayam ca paṭigha anusayam ca māna anusayam ca diṭṭha anusayam ca vicikicchā anusayam ca na ppajahati tatas bhava rāga anusayam na ppajahati iti āmantā
translated: “When he does not abandon the underlying tendency to lust, the underlying tendency to aversion, the underlying tendency to conceit, the underlying tendency to views, and the underlying tendency to doubt, does he then not abandon the underlying tendency to desire for being?” “He does not.”

original: Yato vā pana bhavarāgānusayaṁ nappajahati tato kāmarāgānusayañca paṭighānusayañca mānānusayañca diṭṭhānusayañca vicikicchānusayañca nappajahatīti?
analyzed: yatas vā pana bhava rāga anusayam na ppajahati tatas kāma rāga anusayam ca paṭigha anusayam ca māna anusayam ca diṭṭha anusayam ca vicikicchā anusayam ca na ppajahati iti
translated: Or else, when he does not give rise to the underlying tendency to lust for being, he does not give rise to the underlying tendency to lust for sensual desires, to the underlying tendency to resentment, to the underlying tendency to conceit, to the underlying tendency to views, to the underlying tendency to doubt.

original: Dukkhāya vedanāya tato bhavarāgānusayañca kāmarāgānusayañca mānānusayañca nappajahati,
analyzed: dukkhāya vedanāya tatas bhava rāga anusayañca kāma rāga anusayañca māna anusayañca na ppajahati
translated: With painful feeling, he does not give rise to the underlying tendency to lust for being and to the underlying tendency to conceit,

original: no ca tato paṭighānusayañca diṭṭhānusayañca vicikicchānusayañca nappajahati. Kāmadhātuyā
analyzed: no ca tatas paṭigha anusayañca diṭṭha anusayañca vicikicchā anusayañca na pajahati kāmadhātuyā
translated: but he does not give rise to the underlying tendency to resentment, to the underlying tendency to views, to the underlying tendency to doubt.

original: dvīsu vedanāsu tato bhavarāgānusayañca paṭighānusayañca nappajahati, no ca tato kāmarāgānusayañca🔽mānānusayañca diṭṭhānusayañca vicikicchānusayañca nappajahati. Apariyāpanne tato
analyzed: dvīsu vedanāsu tatas bhava rāga anusayañca paṭigha anusayañca na ppajahati no ca tatas kāma rāga anusayañca  māna anusayañca diṭṭha anusayañca vicikicchā anusayañca na pajahati a pariyāpanne tatas
translated: With the two kinds of feeling in the fine-material and immaterial dhammas, he does not give rise to the underlying tendency to lust for being and to the underlying tendency to resentment,🔽but he does not give rise to the underlying tendency to lust for sensual desires, to the underlying tendency to conceit, to the underlying tendency to views, to the underlying tendency to doubt.

original: bhavarāgānusayañca nappajahati kāmarāgānusayañca paṭighānusayañca mānānusayañca diṭṭhānusayañca🔽vicikicchānusayañca nappajahati.
analyzed: bhava rāga anusayañca na ppajahati kāma rāga anusayañca paṭigha anusayañca māna anusayañca diṭṭha anusayañca 🔽vicikicchā anusayam ca na appajahati
translated: With the unincluded dhammas, he does not give rise to the underlying tendency to lust for being, but he does not give rise to the underlying tendency to lust for sensual desires, to the underlying tendency to resentment, to the underlying tendency to conceit, to the underlying tendency to views, to the underlying tendency to doubt.

original: Yato kāmarāgānusayañca paṭighānusayañca mānānusayañca diṭṭhānusayañca vicikicchānusayañca nappajahati tato avijjānusayaṁ nappajahatīti? Āmantā.🔽Yato vā pana avijjānusayaṁ nappajahati tato kāmarāgānusayañca paṭighānusayañca mānānusayañca diṭṭhānusayañca vicikicchānusayañca nappajahatīti? Āmantā. (Pañcakamūlakaṁ.)
analyzed: yatas kāma rāga anusayam ca paṭigha anusayam ca māna anusayam ca diṭṭha anusayam ca vicikicchā anusayam ca na ppajahati tatas avijjā anusayam na ppajahati iti āmantā  yatas vā pana avijjā anusayam na pajahati tatas kāma rāga anusayam ca paṭigha anusayam ca māna anusayam ca diṭṭha anusayam ca vicikicchā anusayam ca na ppajahati iti āmantā pañcakamūlaka
translated: When one does not abandon the underlying tendency to lust for sensual pleasure, the underlying tendency to aversion, the underlying tendency to conceit, the underlying tendency to views, and the underlying tendency to doubt, does one then not abandon the underlying tendency to ignorance? …🔽When one does not abandon the underlying tendency to ignorance, does one then not abandon the underlying tendency to lust for sensual pleasure, the underlying tendency to aversion, the underlying tendency to conceit, the underlying tendency to views, and the underlying tendency to doubt? …

original: Yato kāmarāgānusayañca paṭighānusayañca mānānusayañca diṭṭhānusayañca vicikicchānusayañca bhavarāgānusayañca nappajahati tato avijjānusayaṁ nappajahatīti? Āmantā.🔽Yato vā pana avijjānusayaṁ nappajahati tato kāmarāgānusayañca paṭighānusayañca mānānusayañca
analyzed: yatas kāma rāga anusayam ca paṭigha anusayam ca māna anusayam ca diṭṭha anusayam ca vicikicchā anusayam ca bhava rāga anusayañca na ppajahati tatas avijjā anusayam na ppajahati iti āmantā  yatas vā pana avijjā anusayam na ppajahati tatas kāma rāga anusayam ca paṭigha anusayam ca māna anusayam ca
translated: When one does not abandon the underlying tendency to lust for sensual pleasure, the underlying tendency to aversion, the underlying tendency to conceit, the underlying tendency to views, the underlying tendency to doubt, and the underlying tendency to lust for existence, does one then not abandon the underlying tendency to ignorance? …

original: diṭṭhānusayañca vicikicchānusayañca bhavarāgānusayañca nappajahatīti? Āmantā. (Chakkamūlakaṁ.)🔽7.2.3.6. Paṭilomapuggalokāsa
analyzed: diṭṭha anusayañca vicikicchā anusayañca bhava rāga anusayañca na ppajahati iti āmantā chakkamūlaka 🔽paṭiloma puggala ukāsa
translated: When one does not abandon the underlying tendency to ignorance, does one then not abandon the underlying tendency to lust for sensual pleasure, the underlying tendency to aversion, the underlying tendency to conceit, the underlying tendency to views, the underlying tendency to doubt, and the underlying tendency to lust for existence? …🔽… in reverse order, starting with the person.

original: Yo yato kāmarāgānusayaṁ nappajahati so tato paṭighānusayaṁ nappajahatīti?🔽Anāgāmimaggasamaṅgī dukkhāya vedanāya so tato kāmarāgānusayaṁ nappajahati, no ca🔽so tato paṭighānusayaṁ nappajahati. Sveva puggalo rūpadhātuyā arūpadhātuyā apariyāpanne
analyzed: yaḥ yatas kāma rāga anusayam na ppajahati saḥ tatas paṭigha anusayam na ppajahati iti  anāgāmi magga samaṅgī dukkhāya vedanāya saḥ tatas kāma rāga anusayam na ppajahati no ca  so tatas paṭigha anusayam na ppajahati sve eva puggalaḥ rūpa dhātuyā arūpa dhātuyā a pariyāpanne
translated: Does anyone who does not abandon the fetter of lust for a given base not abandon the fetter of resentment towards that base?

original: so tato kāmarāgānusayañca nappajahati paṭighānusayañca nappajahati. Anāgāmimaggasamaṅgiṁ
analyzed: so tato kāma rāga anusayañca na pajahati paṭigha anusayañca na pajahati anāgāmi magga samaṅgi
translated: One who possesses the path of non-return does not abandon the fetter of lust for the base of pain, but he does not abandon the fetter of resentment towards that base. That same person does not abandon the fetter of lust for the base of neither-pain-nor-pleasure and for the immaterial states, but he does not abandon the fetter of resentment towards those bases.

original: ṭhapetvā avasesā puggalā sabbattha kāmarāgānusayañca nappajahanti paṭighānusayañca nappajahanti.
analyzed: ṭhapetvā avasesā puggalā sabbattha kāma rāga anusayañca na ppajahanti paṭigha anusayañca na ppajahanti
translated: Excepting one who possesses the path of non-return, all other persons do not abandon the fetter of lust for any base and do not abandon the fetter of resentment towards any base.

original: Yo vā pana yato paṭighānusayaṁ nappajahati so tato kāmarāgānusayaṁ nappajahatīti?🔽Anāgāmimaggasamaṅgī kāmadhātuyā dvīsu vedanāsu so tato paṭighānusayaṁ nappajahati,
analyzed: yaḥ vā pana yatas paṭigha anusayam na ppajahati saḥ tatas kāma rāga anusayam na ppajahati iti  anāgāmi magga samaṅgī kāmadhātuyā dvīsu vedanāsu so tatas paṭigha anusayam na ppajahati
translated: Or does anyone who does not abandon the fetter of resentment for a given base not abandon the fetter of lust for that base?

original: no ca so tato kāmarāgānusayaṁ nappajahati. Sveva puggalo rūpadhātuyā arūpadhātuyā
analyzed: no ca saḥ tatas kāma rāga anusayam na ppajahati su eva puggalaḥ rūpadhātuyā arūpadhātuyā
translated: One who possesses the path of non-return does not abandon the fetter of resentment for the base of sensual desire and for the two higher bases, but he does not abandon the fetter of lust for those bases. That same person does not abandon the fetter of resentment for the base of neither-pain-nor-pleasure and for the immaterial states,

original: apariyāpanne so tato paṭighānusayañca nappajahati kāmarāgānusayañca nappajahati.
analyzed: a pariyāpanne so tatas paṭigha anusayañca na ppajahati kāma rāga anusayañca na ppajahati
translated: in the incon-ceivable he does not abandon the underlying tendency to resistance and he does not abandon the underlying tendency to lust for sensual desires.

original: Anāgāmimaggasamaṅgiṁ ṭhapetvā avasesā puggalā sabbattha paṭighānusayañca nappajahanti
analyzed: anāgāmi magga samaṅgim ṭhapetvā avasesā puggalā sabbattha paṭigha anusayañca na ppajahanti
translated: Except for the person who is possessed of the path of non-return, all other persons do not abandon the underlying tendency to resistance

original: kāmarāgānusayañca nappajahanti.
analyzed: kāma rāga anusayam ca na appajahanti
translated: and they do not abandon the underlying tendency to lust for sensual desires.

original: Yo yato kāmarāgānusayaṁ nappajahati so tato mānānusayaṁ nappajahatīti?🔽Aggamaggasamaṅgī kāmadhātuyā dvīsu vedanāsu rūpadhātuyā arūpadhātuyā so tato kāmarāgānusayaṁ
analyzed: yaḥ yatas kāma rāga anusayam na ppajahati saḥ tatas māna anusayam na ppajahati iti  agga magga samaṅgī kāmadhātuyā dvīsu vedanāsu rūpadhātuyā arūpadhātuyā saḥ tatas kāma rāga anusaya
translated: Does anyone who does not abandon the underlying tendency to lust for sensual desires not abandon the underlying tendency to conceit?🔽One who is possessed of the path of stream-entry does not abandon the underlying tendency to lust for sensual desires🔽in the sense-desire element, in two feelings, in the element of form, and in the formless element, but he does not not abandon the underlying tendency to conceit. That same person

original: nappajahati, no ca so tato mānānusayaṁ nappajahati. Sveva puggalo dukkhāya vedanāya
analyzed: na ppajahati no ca so tatas māna anusayam na ppajahati su eva puggalaḥ dukkhāya vedanāya
translated: in painful feeling

original: apariyāpanne so tato kāmarāgānusayañca nappajahati mānānusayañca nappajahati. Dvinnaṁ
analyzed: a pariyāpanne saḥ tatas kāma rāga anusayañca na ppajahati māna anusayañca na ppajahati
translated: in the incon-ceivable does not abandon the underlying tendency to lust for sensual desires and he does not abandon the underlying tendency to conceit.

original: maggasamaṅgīnaṁ ṭhapetvā avasesā puggalā sabbattha kāmarāgānusayañca nappajahanti
analyzed: magga samaṅgīnam ṭhapetvā avasesā puggalā sabbattha kāma rāga anusayam ca na ppajahanti
translated: Except for the two who are possessed of the paths, all other persons do not abandon the underlying tendency to lust for sensual desires

original: mānānusayañca nappajahanti.
analyzed: māna anusayam ca na ppajahanti
translated: and they do not abandon the underlying tendency to conceit.

original: Yo vā pana yato mānānusayaṁ nappajahati so tato kāmarāgānusayaṁ nappajahatīti?
analyzed: yaḥ vā pana yatas māna anusayam na ppajahati saḥ tatas kāma rāga anusayam na ppajahati iti
translated: Or does anyone who does not abandon the underlying tendency to conceit in regard to anything not abandon the underlying tendency to lust in regard to that?

original: Anāgāmimaggasamaṅgī kāmadhātuyā dvīsu vedanāsu so tato mānānusayaṁ nappajahati, no🔽ca so tato kāmarāgānusayaṁ nappajahati. Sveva puggalo dukkhāya vedanāya rūpadhātuyā
analyzed: anāgāmi magga samaṅgī kāmadhātuyā dvīsu vedanāsu saḥ tatas māna anusayam na ppajahati no  ca so tatas kāma rāga anusayam na ppajahati su eva puggalaḥ dukkhāya vedanāya rūpa dhātuyā
translated: One who possesses the path of non-return does not abandon the underlying tendency to conceit in regard to the two kinds of feeling in the sense-desire element,🔽but he does not abandon the underlying tendency to lust in regard to them. That same person does not abandon the underlying tendency to conceit in regard to painful feeling in the fine-material and immaterial elements,

original: arūpadhātuyā apariyāpanne so tato mānānusayañca nappajahati kāmarāgānusayañca nappajahati.🔽Dvinnaṁ maggasamaṅgīnaṁ ṭhapetvā avasesā puggalā sabbattha mānānusayañca nappajahanti
analyzed: arūpadhātuyāḥ apariyāpanne saḥ tatas māna anusayañca na ppajahati kāma rāga anusayañca na ppajahati  dvinnam magga samaṅgīnam ṭhapetvā avasesā puggalā sabbattha māna anusayam ca na ppajahanti
translated: and he does not abandon the underlying tendency to lust in regard to it.🔽Except for those possessing two paths, the rest do not abandon the underlying tendency to conceit in regard to anything,

original: kāmarāgānusayañca nappajahanti.
analyzed: kāma rāga anusayam ca na appajahanti
translated: and they do not abandon the underlying tendency to lust in regard to anything.

original: Yo yato kāmarāgānusayaṁ nappajahati so tato diṭṭhānusayaṁ …pe… vicikicchānusayaṁ nappajahatīti?
analyzed: yaḥ yatas kāma rāga anusayam na ppajahati saḥ tatas diṭṭha anusayam pe vicikicchā anusayam na ppajahati iti
translated: Does anyone who does not abandon the underlying tendency to lust in regard to anything not abandon the underlying tendency to false view … the underlying tendency to conceit … the underlying tendency to lust for existence … the underlying tendency to conceit … the underlying tendency to ignorance in regard to that?

original: Aṭṭhamako kāmadhātuyā tīsu vedanāsu rūpadhātuyā arūpadhātuyā so tato kāmarāgānusayaṁ
analyzed: aṭṭhamako kāmadhātuyā tīsu vedanāsu rūpadhātuyā arūpadhātuyā so tato kāma rāga anusaya
translated: One in the eighth generation in the sense-desire element in regard to the three kinds of feeling in the fine-material and immaterial elements does not abandon the underlying tendency to lust in regard to them,

original: nappajahati, no ca so tato vicikicchānusayaṁ nappajahati. Sveva puggalo apariyāpanne
analyzed: na ppajahati no ca so tatas vicikicchā anusayam na ppajahati su eva puggalaḥ a pariyāpanne
translated: he does not abandon the underlying tendency to lust for sensual desires, but he does not abandon the underlying tendency to uncertainty.

original: so tato kāmarāgānusayañca nappajahati vicikicchānusayañca nappajahati. Anāgāmimaggasamaṅgiñca
analyzed: so tato kāma rāga anusayañca na ppajahati vicikicchā anusayañca na ppajahati anāgāmi magga samaṅgiñca
translated: This person does not abandon the underlying tendency to lust for sensual desires and the underlying tendency to uncertainty.

original: aṭṭhamakañca ṭhapetvā avasesā puggalā sabbattha kāmarāgānusayañca nappajahanti vicikicchānusayañca nappajahanti.
analyzed: aṭṭhamakañca ṭhapetvā avasesā puggalā sabbattha kāma rāga anusayañca na ppajahanti vicikicchā anusayañca na ppajahanti
translated: Except for the one who possesses the path of non-return and the eighth person, the remaining persons do not abandon the underlying tendency to lust for sensual desires and the underlying tendency to uncertainty.

original: Yo vā pana yato vicikicchānusayaṁ nappajahati so tato kāmarāgānusayaṁ nappajahatīti?
analyzed: yaḥ vā pana yatas vicikicchā anusayam na ppajahati saḥ tatas kāma rāga anusayam na ppajahati iti
translated: Or, if someone does not abandon the underlying tendency to uncertainty in regard to a certain object, does he not abandon the underlying tendency to lust for sensual desires in regard to that object?

original: Anāgāmimaggasamaṅgī kāmadhātuyā dvīsu vedanāsu so tato vicikicchānusayaṁ nappajahati,
analyzed: anāgāmi magga samaṅgī kāmadhātuyā dvīsu vedanāsu saḥ tatas vicikicchā anusayam na ppajahati
translated: One who possesses the path of non-return does not abandon the underlying tendency to uncertainty in regard to the two kinds of feeling in the sense-desire element,

original: no ca so tato kāmarāgānusayaṁ nappajahati. Sveva puggalo dukkhāya vedanāya rūpadhātuyā
analyzed: no ca so tatas kāma rāga anusayam na ppajahati su eva puggalaḥ dukkhāya vedanāya rūpa dhātuyā
translated: but he does not abandon the underlying tendency to lust for sensual desires. This same person does not abandon the underlying tendency to uncertainty in regard to painful feeling, in regard to the form element,

original: arūpadhātuyā apariyāpanne so tato vicikicchānusayañca nappajahati kāmarāgānusayañca
analyzed: arūpadhātuyāḥ apariyāpanne saḥ tatas vicikicchā anusayañca na ppajahati kāma rāga anusayañca
translated: in regard to the formless element, and in regard to what is unincluded. He does not abandon the underlying tendency to lust for sensual desires and the underlying tendency to uncertainty.

original: nappajahati. Anāgāmimaggasamaṅgiñca aṭṭhamakañca ṭhapetvā avasesā puggalā sabbattha
analyzed: na ppajahati anāgāmi magga samaṅgiñca aṭṭhamakañca ṭhapetvā avasesā puggalā sabbattha
translated: except for the one who possesses the path of non-return and the one on the eighth path, all other persons

original: vicikicchānusayañca nappajahanti kāmarāgānusayañca nappajahanti.
analyzed: vicikicchā anusayañca na ppajahanti kāma rāga anusayañca na ppajahanti
translated: do not abandon the underlying tendency to uncertainty and do not abandon the underlying tendency to lust for sensual desires.

original: Yo yato kāmarāgānusayaṁ nappajahati so tato bhavarāgānusayaṁ nappajahatīti?
analyzed: yaḥ yatas kāma rāga anusayam na ppajahati saḥ tatas bhava rāga anusayam na ppajahati iti
translated: Does anyone not abandon the underlying tendency to lust for sensual desires from anywhere?

original: Aggamaggasamaṅgī rūpadhātuyā arūpadhātuyā so tato kāmarāgānusayaṁ nappajahati, no🔽ca so tato bhavarāgānusayaṁ nappajahati. Sveva puggalo kāmadhātuyā tīsu vedanāsu
analyzed: agga magga samaṅgī rūpadhātuyā arūpadhātuyā saḥ tatas kāma rāga anusayam na ppajahati no  ca so tatas bhava rāga anusayam na ppajahati su eva puggalaḥ kāmadhātuyā tīsu vedanāsu
translated: One who possesses the path of seeing does not abandon the underlying tendency to lust for sensual desires from the fine-material and immaterial dhammas,

original: apariyāpanne so tato kāmarāgānusayañca nappajahati bhavarāgānusayañca nappajahati.🔽Dvinnaṁ maggasamaṅgīnaṁ ṭhapetvā avasesā puggalā sabbattha kāmarāgānusayañca nappajahanti
analyzed: a pariyāpanne so tatas kāma rāga anusayañca na ppajahati bhava rāga anusayañca na ppajahati  dvinnam magga samaṅgīnam ṭhapetvā avasesā puggalā sabbattha kāma rāga anusayam ca na ppajahanti
translated: but he does not abandon the underlying tendency to lust for existence from anywhere. That same person does not abandon the underlying tendency to lust for sensual desires and does not abandon the underlying tendency to lust for existence from the three kinds of feeling in the sensual-desire element🔽and from the unincluded dhammas.

original: bhavarāgānusayañca nappajahanti.
analyzed: bhava rāga anusayam ca na ppajahanti
translated: Except for the two who possess the paths, all other persons do not abandon the underlying tendency to lust for sensual desires and do not abandon the underlying tendency to lust for existence from anywhere.

original: Yo vā pana yato bhavarāgānusayaṁ nappajahati so tato kāmarāgānusayaṁ nappajahatīti?
analyzed: yaḥ vā pana yatas bhava rāga anusayam na ppajahati saḥ tatas kāma rāga anusayam na ppajahati iti
translated: Does anyone not abandon the underlying tendency to lust for existence from anywhere?

original: Anāgāmimaggasamaṅgī kāmadhātuyā dvīsu vedanāsu so tato bhavarāgānusayaṁ nappajahati,
analyzed: anāgāmi magga samaṅgī kāmadhātuyā dvīsu vedanāsu saḥ tatas bhava rāga anusayam na ppajahati
translated: One who possesses the path of non-return does not abandon the underlying tendency to lust for existence in the two kinds of feeling in the sense sphere,

original: no ca so tato kāmarāgānusayaṁ nappajahati. Sveva puggalo dukkhāya vedanāya rūpadhātuyā
analyzed: no ca so tatas kāma rāga anusayam na ppajahati su eva puggalaḥ dukkhāya vedanāya rūpa dhātuyā
translated: but he does not abandon the underlying tendency to lust for sensual desires there. That same person in painful feeling in the fine-material and immaterial dhammas,

original: arūpadhātuyā apariyāpanne so tato bhavarāgānusayañca nappajahati kāmarāgānusayañca🔽nappajahati. Dvinnaṁ maggasamaṅgīnaṁ ṭhapetvā avasesā puggalā sabbattha bhavarāgānusayañca
analyzed: arūpadhātuyāḥ apariyāpanne saḥ tatas bhava rāga anusayañca na ppajahati kāma rāga anusayañca  na ppajahati dvinnam magga samaṅgīnam ṭhapetvā avasesā puggalā sabbattha bhava rāga anusayam ca
translated: and in the unincluded dhammas does not abandon the underlying tendency to lust for existence there, nor does he abandon the underlying tendency to lust for sensual desires there.

original: nappajahanti kāmarāgānusayañca nappajahanti.
analyzed: na ppajahanti kāma rāga anusayam ca na ppajahanti
translated: Except for two kinds of persons who possess the paths, the rest do not abandon the underlying tendency to lust for existence and the underlying tendency to lust for sensual desires in any of the dhammas.

original: Yo yato kāmarāgānusayaṁ nappajahati so tato avijjānusayaṁ nappajahatīti?
analyzed: yaḥ yatas kāma rāga anusayam na ppajahati saḥ tatas avijjā anusayam na ppajahati iti
translated: As to the question, “When anyone does not abandon the underlying tendency to lust for sensual desires in regard to any state, does he thereby not abandon the underlying tendency to ignorance in regard to that state? “

original: Aggamaggasamaṅgī kāmadhātuyā tīsu vedanāsu rūpadhātuyā arūpadhātuyā so tato kāmarāgānusayaṁ
analyzed: agga magga samaṅgī kāmadhātuyā tīsu vedanāsu rūpadhātuyā arūpadhātuyā saḥ tatas kāma rāga anusaya
translated: One who possesses the path of stream-entry does not abandon the underlying tendency to lust for sensual desires in the three kinds of feeling in the sense sphere, in the fine-material and immaterial dhammas,

original: nappajahati, no ca so tato avijjānusayaṁ nappajahati. Sveva puggalo apariyāpanne
analyzed: na ppajahati no ca so tatas avijjā anusayam na ppajahati su eva puggalaḥ a pariyāpanne
translated: but he does not abandon the underlying tendency to ignorance in the unincluded dhammas.

original: so tato kāmarāgānusayañca nappajahati avijjānusayañca nappajahati. Dvinnaṁ maggasamaṅgīnaṁ
analyzed: so tato kāma rāga anusayam ca na ppajahati avijjā anusayam ca na ppajahati dvinnam
translated: he does not abandon the underlying tendency to lust for sensual desires and he does not abandon the underlying tendency to ignorance.🔽Except for two persons possessed of the paths,

original: ṭhapetvā avasesā puggalā sabbattha kāmarāgānusayañca nappajahanti avijjānusayañca nappajahanti.
analyzed: ṭhapetvā avasesā puggalā sabbattha kāma rāga anusayañca na ppajahanti avijjā anusayañca na ppajahanti
translated: all other persons do not abandon the underlying tendency to lust for sensual desires and they do not abandon the underlying tendency to ignorance.

original: Yo vā pana yato avijjānusayaṁ nappajahati so tato kāmarāgānusayaṁ nappajahatīti?
analyzed: yaḥ vā pana yatas avijjā anusayam na ppajahati saḥ tatas kāma rāga anusayam na ppajahati iti
translated: Or, does anyone who does not abandon the underlying tendency to ignorance in regard to a given state not abandon the underlying tendency to lust for sensual desires in regard to that state?

original: Anāgāmimaggasamaṅgī kāmadhātuyā dvīsu vedanāsu so tato avijjānusayaṁ nappajahati,🔽no ca so tato kāmarāgānusayaṁ nappajahati. Sveva puggalo dukkhāya vedanāya rūpadhātuyā
analyzed: anāgāmi magga samaṅgī kāmadhātuyā dvīsu vedanāsu saḥ tatas avijjā anusayam na ppajahati  no ca so tatas kāma rāga anusayam na ppajahati su eva puggalaḥ dukkhāya vedanāya rūpa dhātuyā
translated: One who is possessed of the path of non-return does not abandon the underlying tendency to ignorance in regard to the two kinds of feeling associated with the sensual realm,🔽but he does not not abandon the underlying tendency to lust for sensual desires in regard to them. That same person does not abandon the underlying tendency to ignorance in regard to painful feeling, in regard to the fine-material and immaterial realms, and in regard to the unincluded states,

original: arūpadhātuyā apariyāpanne so tato avijjānusayañca nappajahati kāmarāgānusayañca nappajahati.
analyzed: arūpadhātuyāḥ apariyāpanne saḥ tatas avijjā anusayañca na ppajahati kāma rāga anusayañca na ppajahati
translated: but he does not abandon the underlying tendency to lust for sensual desires in regard to them.🔽Except for two persons possessed of the paths,

original: Dvinnaṁ maggasamaṅgīnaṁ ṭhapetvā avasesā puggalā sabbattha avijjānusayañca nappajahanti
analyzed: dvinnam magga samaṅgīnam ṭhapetvā avasesā puggalā sabbattha avijjā anusayam ca na ppajahanti
translated: all other persons do not abandon the underlying tendency to ignorance in regard to any state,

original: kāmarāgānusayañca nappajahanti.
analyzed: kāma rāga anusayam ca na appajahanti
translated: and they do not abandon the underlying tendency to lust for sensual desires in regard to any state.

original: Yo yato paṭighānusayaṁ nappajahati so tato mānānusayaṁ nappajahatīti?
analyzed: yaḥ yatas paṭigha anusayam na ppajahati saḥ tatas māna anusayam na ppajahati iti
translated: Does anyone not abandon the underlying tendency to resistance from which he does not abandon the underlying tendency to conceit?

original: Aggamaggasamaṅgī kāmadhātuyā dvīsu vedanāsu rūpadhātuyā arūpadhātuyā so tato paṭighānusayaṁ🔽nappajahati, no ca so tato mānānusayaṁ nappajahati. Sveva puggalo dukkhāya vedanāya🔽apariyāpanne so tato paṭighānusayañca nappajahati mānānusayañca nappajahati. Dvinnaṁ
analyzed: agga magga samaṅgī kāmadhātuyā dvīsu vedanāsu rūpadhātuyā arūpadhātuyā saḥ tatas paṭigha anusaya  na ppajahati no ca so tatas māna anusayam na ppajahati su eva puggalaḥ dukkhāya vedanāya  a pariyāpanne so tatas paṭigha anusayam ca na ppajahati māna anusayam ca na ppajahati
translated: One possessing the path of Stream-Entry does not abandon the underlying tendency to resistance in the sense-desire element and in two of the feelings in the form element and in the formless element,🔽but he does not abandon the underlying tendency to conceit there. That same person does not abandon the underlying tendency to resistance and does not abandon the underlying tendency to conceit in painful feeling.

original: maggasamaṅgīnaṁ ṭhapetvā avasesā puggalā sabbattha paṭighānusayañca nappajahanti🔽mānānusayañca nappajahanti.
analyzed: magga samaṅgīnam ṭhapetvā avasesā puggalā sabbattha paṭigha anusayam ca na pajahanti  māna anusayam ca na ppajahanti
translated: Except for two kinds of persons possessing the path of Non-Returner, the rest do not abandon the underlying tendency to resistance and do not abandon the underlying tendency to conceit in any of the three elements.

original: Yo vā pana yato mānānusayaṁ nappajahati so tato paṭighānusayaṁ nappajahatīti?🔽Anāgāmimaggasamaṅgī dukkhāya vedanāya so tato mānānusayaṁ nappajahati, no ca so tato
analyzed: yaḥ vā pana yatas māna anusayam na ppajahati so tatas paṭigha anusayam na ppajahati iti  anāgāmi magga samaṅgī dukkhāya vedanāya so tatas māna anusayam na ppajahati no ca so tatas
translated: Or does anyone not abandon the underlying tendency to conceit from which he does not abandon the underlying tendency to resistance?

original: paṭighānusayaṁ nappajahati. Sveva puggalo kāmadhātuyā dvīsu vedanāsu rūpadhātuyā
analyzed: paṭigha anusayam na ppajahati su eva puggalaḥ kāmadhātuyā dvīsu vedanāsu rūpadhātuyā
translated: One possessing the path of Non-Returner does not abandon the underlying tendency to conceit in painful feeling, but he does not abandon the underlying tendency to resistance there. That same person does not abandon the underlying tendency to conceit and does not abandon the underlying tendency to resistance in the sense-desire element and in two of the feelings in the form element and in the formless element.

original: arūpadhātuyā apariyāpanne so tato mānānusayañca nappajahati paṭighānusayañca nappajahati.
analyzed: arūpa dhātuyāḥ apariyāpanne saḥ tatas māna anusayam ca na pajahati paṭigha anusayam ca na pajahati
translated: in the immaterial sphere, he does not abandon the underlying tendency to conceit there, nor does he abandon the underlying tendency to resistance there.🔽Except for two persons possessing the path,

original: Dvinnaṁ maggasamaṅgīnaṁ ṭhapetvā avasesā puggalā sabbattha mānānusayañca nappajahanti🔽paṭighānusayañca nappajahanti.
analyzed: dvinnam magga samaṅgīnam ṭhapetvā avasesā puggalā sabbattha māna anusayam ca na ppajahanti  paṭigha anusayam ca na ppajahanti
translated: all other persons do not abandon the underlying tendency to conceit and the underlying tendency to resistance in any of the three planes.

original: Yo yato paṭighānusayaṁ nappajahati so tato diṭṭhānusayaṁ …pe… vicikicchānusayaṁ nappajahatīti?
analyzed: yaḥ yatas paṭigha anusayam na ppajahati so tatas diṭṭha anusayam pe vicikicchā anusayam na ppajahati iti
translated: In regard to any given state, if someone does not abandon the underlying tendency to resistance in that state, does he not abandon the underlying tendency to false view … the underlying tendency to doubt in that state?

original: Aṭṭhamako kāmadhātuyā tīsu vedanāsu rūpadhātuyā arūpadhātuyā so tato paṭighānusayaṁ🔽nappajahati, no ca so tato vicikicchānusayaṁ nappajahati. Sveva puggalo apariyāpanne🔽so tato paṭighānusayañca nappajahati vicikicchānusayañca nappajahati. Anāgāmimaggasamaṅgiñca
analyzed: aṭṭhamako kāmadhātuyā tīsu vedanāsu rūpadhātuyā arūpadhātuyā so tato paṭigha anusaya  na ppajahati no ca so tatas vicikicchā anusayam na ppajahati su eva puggalaḥ a pariyāpanne  so tato paṭigha anusayañca na ppajahati vicikicchā anusayañca na ppajahati anāgāmi magga samaṅgiñca
translated: One in the eighth generation in the sense sphere and in the three kinds of feeling in the fine-material and immaterial spheres does not abandon the underlying tendency to resistance there,🔽but he does not abandon the underlying tendency to doubt there. That same person in the imperturbable does not abandon the underlying tendency to resistance there,🔽nor does he abandon the underlying tendency to doubt there. Except for one possessing the non-return path and one in the eighth generation,

original: aṭṭhamakañca ṭhapetvā avasesā puggalā sabbattha paṭighānusayañca nappajahanti vicikicchānusayañca nappajahanti.
analyzed: aṭṭhamakañca ṭhapetvā avasesā puggalā sabbattha paṭigha anusayañca na ppajahanti vicikicchā anusayañca na ppajahanti
translated: all other persons do not abandon the underlying tendency to resistance and the underlying tendency to doubt in any of the three planes.

original: Yo vā pana yato vicikicchānusayaṁ nappajahati so tato paṭighānusayaṁ nappajahatīti?
analyzed: yaḥ vā pana yatas vicikicchā anusayam na ppajahati so tatas paṭigha anusayam na ppajahati iti
translated: Or does anyone who does not abandon the underlying tendency to uncertainty about that not abandon the underlying tendency to resentment about that?

original: Anāgāmimaggasamaṅgī dukkhāya vedanāya so tato vicikicchānusayaṁ nappajahati, no ca🔽so tato paṭighānusayaṁ nappajahati. Sveva puggalo kāmadhātuyā dvīsu vedanāsu rūpadhātuyā
analyzed: anāgāmi magga samaṅgī dukkhāya vedanāya saḥ tatas vicikicchā anusayam na ppajahati no ca  so tatas paṭigha anusayam na ppajahati su eva puggalaḥ kāmadhātuyā dvīsu vedanāsu rūpadhātuyā
translated: One who possesses the path of non-return does not abandon the underlying tendency to uncertainty about painful feeling, but he does not abandon the underlying tendency to resentment about that.🔽That same person does not abandon the underlying tendency to uncertainty about the two kinds of feeling in the sense-desire element and the underlying tendency to resentment about that.

original: arūpadhātuyā apariyāpanne so tato vicikicchānusayañca nappajahati paṭighānusayañca🔽nappajahati. Anāgāmimaggasamaṅgiñca aṭṭhamakañca ṭhapetvā avasesā puggalā sabbattha
analyzed: arūpa dhātuyāḥ apariyāpanne saḥ tatas vicikicchā anusayam ca na ppajahati paṭigha anusayam ca  na ppajahati anāgāmi magga samaṅgiñca aṭṭhamakañca ṭhapetvā avasesā puggalā sabbattha
translated: He does not abandon the underlying tendency to uncertainty about the two kinds of feeling in the fine-material and immaterial elements and the underlying tendency to resentment about that.

original: vicikicchānusayañca nappajahanti paṭighānusayañca nappajahanti.
analyzed: vicikicchā anusayañca na ppajahanti paṭigha anusayañca na ppajahanti
translated: Except for one who possesses the path of non-return and the eighth person, the remaining persons do not abandon the underlying tendency to uncertainty about that and do not abandon the underlying tendency to resentment about that.

original: Yo yato paṭighānusayaṁ nappajahati so tato bhavarāgānusayaṁ nappajahatīti?
analyzed: yaḥ yatas paṭigha anusayam na ppajahati saḥ tatas bhava rāga anusayam na ppajahati iti
translated: Does anyone who does not abandon the underlying tendency to resentment about that not abandon the underlying tendency to lust for existence about that?

original: Aggamaggasamaṅgī rūpadhātuyā arūpadhātuyā so tato paṭighānusayaṁ nappajahati, no
analyzed: agga magga samaṅgī rūpadhātuyā arūpadhātuyā saḥ tatas paṭigha anusayam na ppajahati no
translated: One who possesses the path of stream-entry does not abandon the underlying tendency to resentment about the fine-material and immaterial elements, but he does not abandon the underlying tendency to lust for existence about that.

original: ca so tato bhavarāgānusayaṁ nappajahati. Sveva puggalo kāmadhātuyā tīsu vedanāsu
analyzed: ca so tatas bhava rāga anusayam na ppajahati su eva puggalaḥ kāmadhātuyā tīsu vedanāsu
translated: This person, in the three kinds of feeling not included in the fine-material and immaterial dhammas,

original: apariyāpanne so tato paṭighānusayañca nappajahati bhavarāgānusayañca nappajahati.
analyzed: a pariyāpanne so tatas paṭigha anusayañca na ppajahati bhava rāga anusayañca na ppajahati
translated: does not abandon the underlying tendency to resentment there and he does not abandon the underlying tendency to lust for being there.

original: Dvinnaṁ maggasamaṅgīnaṁ ṭhapetvā avasesā puggalā sabbattha paṭighānusayañca nappajahanti
analyzed: dvinnam magga samaṅgīnam ṭhapetvā avasesā puggalā sabbattha paṭigha anusayam ca na pajahanti
translated: Except for those possessing the first two paths, the rest do not abandon the underlying tendency to resentment there and

original: bhavarāgānusayañca nappajahanti.
analyzed: bhava rāga anusayam ca na ppajahanti
translated: they do not abandon the underlying tendency to lust for being there.

original: Yo vā pana yato bhavarāgānusayaṁ nappajahati so tato paṭighānusayaṁ nappajahatīti?
analyzed: yaḥ vā pana yatas bhava rāga anusayam na ppajahati saḥ tatas paṭigha anusayam na ppajahati iti
translated: Or, does anyone who does not abandon the underlying tendency to lust for being there not abandon the underlying tendency to resentment there too?

original: Anāgāmimaggasamaṅgī dukkhāya vedanāya so tato bhavarāgānusayaṁ nappajahati, no ca🔽so tato paṭighānusayaṁ nappajahati. Sveva puggalo kāmadhātuyā dvīsu vedanāsu rūpadhātuyā
analyzed: anāgāmi magga samaṅgī dukkhāya vedanāya saḥ tatas bhava rāga anusayam na ppajahati no ca  so tatas paṭigha anusayam na ppajahati su eva puggalaḥ kāmadhātuyā dvīsu vedanāsu rūpadhātuyā
translated: The non-returner who possesses the path of non-return does not abandon the underlying tendency to lust for being there in painful feeling, but🔽he does not abandon the underlying tendency to resentment there. This person, in the two kinds of feeling in the sense sphere and

original: arūpadhātuyā apariyāpanne so tato bhavarāgānusayañca nappajahati paṭighānusayañca
analyzed: arūpa dhātuyāḥ apariyāpanne saḥ tatas bhava rāga anusayam ca na pajahati paṭigha anusayam ca
translated: in the fine-material and immaterial dhammas not included in the three kinds of feeling, does not abandon the underlying tendency to lust for being there and he does not abandon the underlying tendency to resentment there.

original: nappajahati. Dvinnaṁ maggasamaṅgīnaṁ ṭhapetvā avasesā puggalā sabbattha bhavarāgānusayañca
analyzed: na ppajahati dvinnam magga samaṅgīnam ṭhapetvā avasesā puggalā sabbattha bhava rāga anusayam ca
translated: does not abandon. Except for two persons possessing the path, the rest of the persons in all cases have the underlying tendency to lust for being.

original: nappajahanti paṭighānusayañca nappajahanti.🔽Yo yato paṭighānusayaṁ nappajahati so tato avijjānusayaṁ nappajahatīti?
analyzed: na ppajahanti paṭigha anusayam ca na ppajahanti  yaḥ yatas paṭigha anusayam na ppajahati saḥ tatas avijjā anusayam na ppajahati iti
translated: does not abandon the fetter of resentment.🔽Except for two persons—🔽one who is possessed of the path of Stream-Entry and one who is possessed of the path of Arahatship—

original: Aggamaggasamaṅgī kāmadhātuyā tīsu vedanāsu rūpadhātuyā arūpadhātuyā so tato paṭighānusayaṁ
analyzed: agga magga samaṅgī kāmadhātuyā tīsu vedanāsu rūpadhātuyā arūpadhātuyā saḥ tatas paṭigha anusaya
translated: the remaining persons do not abandon the fetter of resentment in any of the three realms.🔽The fetter of ignorance is not abandoned in any of the three realms.

original: nappajahati, no ca so tato avijjānusayaṁ nappajahati. Sveva puggalo apariyāpanne
analyzed: na ppajahati no ca so tatas avijjā anusayam na ppajahati su eva puggalaḥ a pariyāpanne
translated: The fetter of resentment is not abandoned in any of the three realms.🔽The fetter of ignorance is not abandoned in any of the three realms.

original: so tato paṭighānusayañca nappajahati avijjānusayañca nappajahati. Dvinnaṁ maggasamaṅgīnaṁ
analyzed: so tatas paṭigha anusayam ca na ppajahati avijjā anusayam ca na ppajahati dvinnam
translated: The fetter of resentment is not abandoned in any of the three realms.

original: ṭhapetvā avasesā puggalā sabbattha paṭighānusayañca nappajahanti avijjānusayañca nappajahanti.🔽Yo vā pana yato avijjānusayaṁ nappajahati so tato paṭighānusayaṁ nappajahatīti?
analyzed: ṭhapetvā avasesā puggalā sabbattha paṭigha anusayañca na ppajahanti avijjā anusayañca na ppajahanti 🔽yaḥ vā pana yatas avijjā anusayam na ppajahati saḥ tatas paṭigha anusayam na ppajahati iti
translated: The fetter of ignorance is not abandoned in any of the three realms.

original: Anāgāmimaggasamaṅgī dukkhāya vedanāya so tato avijjānusayaṁ nappajahati, no ca so🔽tato paṭighānusayaṁ nappajahati. Sveva puggalo kāmadhātuyā dvīsu vedanāsu rūpadhātuyā
analyzed: anāgāmi magga samaṅgī dukkhāya vedanāya so tatas avijjā anusayam na ppajahati no ca so  tatas paṭigha anusayam na ppajahati su eva puggalaḥ kāmadhātuyā dvīsu vedanāsu rūpadhātuyā

original: arūpadhātuyā apariyāpanne so tato avijjānusayañca nappajahati paṭighānusayañca nappajahati.
analyzed: arūpa dhātuyāḥ apariyāpanne saḥ tatas avijjā anusayañca na ppajahati paṭigha anusayañca na ppajahati
translated: This same person does not abandon the underlying tendency to ignorance and the underlying tendency to repugnance in regard to the two kinds of feeling in the sense-desire element and in the fine-material element and the immaterial element.

original: Dvinnaṁ maggasamaṅgīnaṁ ṭhapetvā avasesā puggalā sabbattha avijjānusayañca nappajahanti🔽paṭighānusayañca nappajahanti.
analyzed: dvinnam magga samaṅgīnam ṭhapetvā avasesā puggalā sabbattha avijjā anusayam ca na ppajahanti  paṭigha anusayam ca na ppajahanti
translated: Except for two kinds of persons possessing the paths, the rest do not abandon the underlying tendency to ignorance and the underlying tendency to repugnance in regard to all.

original: Yo yato mānānusayaṁ nappajahati so tato diṭṭhānusayaṁ …pe… vicikicchānusayaṁ nappajahatīti?
analyzed: yaḥ yatas māna anusayam na ppajahati saḥ tatas diṭṭha anusayam pe vicikicchā anusayam na ppajahati iti
translated: One who does not abandon the underlying tendency to conceit in regard to any state, does he not abandon the underlying tendency to false view … the underlying tendency to uncertainty in regard to that state?

original: Aṭṭhamako kāmadhātuyā tīsu vedanāsu rūpadhātuyā arūpadhātuyā so tato mānānusayaṁ
analyzed: aṭṭhamako kāmadhātuyā tīsu vedanāsu rūpadhātuyā arūpadhātuyā so tatas māna anusaya
translated: One in his eighth existence does not abandon the underlying tendency to conceit in regard to the three kinds of feeling in the sense-desire element and in the fine-material element and the immaterial element,

original: nappajahati, no ca so tato vicikicchānusayaṁ nappajahati. Sveva puggalo apariyāpanne
analyzed: na ppajahati no ca so tatas vicikicchā anusayam na ppajahati su eva puggalaḥ a pariyāpanne
translated: but he does not abandon the underlying tendency to uncertainty in regard to them. This same person does not abandon the underlying tendency to conceit and the underlying tendency to uncertainty in regard to the unincluded.

original: so tato mānānusayañca nappajahati vicikicchānusayañca nappajahati. Aggamaggasamaṅgiñca
analyzed: saḥ tatas māna anusayañca na ppajahati vicikicchā anusayañca na ppajahati aggamagga samaṅgiñca

original: aṭṭhamakañca ṭhapetvā avasesā puggalā sabbattha mānānusayañca nappajahanti vicikicchānusayañca nappajahanti.
analyzed: aṭṭhamakañca ṭhapetvā avasesā puggalā sabbattha māna anusayañca na ppajahanti vicikicchā anusayañca na ppajahanti
translated: Except in the case of one who possesses the path of stream-entry and the eighth person, all other persons do not abandon the underlying tendency to conceit and the underlying tendency to scepticism in any of the three planes.

original: Yo vā pana yato vicikicchānusayaṁ nappajahati so tato mānānusayaṁ nappajahatīti?
analyzed: yaḥ vā pana yatas vicikicchā anusayam na ppajahati saḥ tatas māna anusayam na ppajahati iti
translated: Or, does anyone not abandon the underlying tendency to scepticism in regard to any of the three planes without abandoning the underlying tendency to conceit?

analyzed: agga magga samaṅgī kāmadhātuyā dvīsu vedanāsu rūpadhātuyā arūpadhātuyā saḥ tatas vicikicchā anusaya  na ppajahati no ca so tatas māna anusayam na ppajahati su eva puggalaḥ dukkhāya vedanāya  a pariyāpanne so tatas vicikicchā anusayañca na ppajahati māna anusayañca na ppajahati aggamagga samaṅgiñca
translated: One who possesses the path of stream-entry does not abandon the underlying tendency to scepticism in the sense-desire element and in two of the feelings in the fine-material and immaterial elements,🔽but he does not abandon the underlying tendency to conceit in any of the three planes. That same person

original: aṭṭhamakañca ṭhapetvā avasesā puggalā sabbattha vicikicchānusayañca nappajahanti🔽mānānusayañca nappajahanti.
analyzed: aṭṭhamakañca ṭhapetvā avasesā puggalā sabbattha vicikicchā anusayañca na ppajahanti 🔽māna anusayam ca na ppajahanti
translated: does not abandon the underlying tendency to scepticism and the underlying tendency to conceit in painful feeling. Except in the case of one who possesses the path of stream-entry and the eighth person, all other persons do not abandon the underlying tendency to scepticism and the underlying tendency to conceit in any of the three planes.

original: Yo yato mānānusayaṁ nappajahati so tato bhavarāgānusayaṁ nappajahatīti? Āmantā.
analyzed: yaḥ yatas māna anusayam na ppajahati saḥ tatas bhava rāga anusayam na ppajahati iti āmantā
translated: Does anyone who does not abandon the underlying tendency to conceit with regard to anything not abandon the underlying tendency to lust for being with regard to that?

original: Yo vā pana yato bhavarāgānusayaṁ nappajahati so tato mānānusayaṁ nappajahatīti?
analyzed: yaḥ vā pana yatas bhava rāga anusayam na ppajahati saḥ tatas māna anusayam na ppajahati iti
translated: Or does anyone who does not abandon the underlying tendency to lust for being with regard to anything not abandon the underlying tendency to conceit with regard to that?

original: Aggamaggasamaṅgī kāmadhātuyā dvīsu vedanāsu so tato bhavarāgānusayaṁ nappajahati,🔽no ca so tato mānānusayaṁ nappajahati. Sveva puggalo dukkhāya vedanāya apariyāpanne
analyzed: agga magga samaṅgī kāmadhātuyā dvīsu vedanāsu saḥ tatas bhava rāga anusayam na ppajahati  no ca so tatas māna anusayam na ppajahati su eva puggalaḥ dukkhāya vedanāya apariyāpanne

analyzed: ṭhapetvā avasesā puggalā sabbattha bhava rāga anusayañca na ppajahanti māna anusayañca na ppajahanti

original: Yo yato mānānusayaṁ nappajahati so tato avijjānusayaṁ nappajahatīti?
analyzed: yaḥ yatas māna anusayam na ppajahati saḥ tatas avijjā anusayam na ppajahati iti

original: Yo yato kāmarāgānusayañca paṭighānusayañca nappajahati so tato avijjānusayaṁ nappajahatīti?
analyzed: yaḥ yatas kāma rāga anusayam ca paṭigha anusayam ca na ppajahati saḥ tatas avijjā anusayam na ppajahati iti
translated: Does anyone not abandon the underlying tendency to ignorance in any given instance where he does not abandon the underlying tendency to lust for sensual pleasure and the underlying tendency to repugnance?

original: Aggamaggasamaṅgī kāmadhātuyā tīsu vedanāsu rūpadhātuyā arūpadhātuyā so tato kāmarāgānusayañca
analyzed: agga magga samaṅgī kāmadhātuyā tīsu vedanāsu rūpadhātuyā arūpadhātuyā saḥ tatas kāma rāga anusayam ca
translated: One possessing the path of Stream-Entry abandons the underlying tendency to lust for sensual desires and the underlying tendency to aversion in three kinds of feeling in the sense-desire element, in the fine-material element, and in the immaterial element,

original: paṭighānusayañca nappajahati, no ca so tato avijjānusayaṁ nappajahati. Sveva puggalo
analyzed: paṭigha anusayam ca na ppajahati no ca so tatas avijjā anusayam na ppajahati su eva puggalo
translated: but he does not abandon the underlying tendency to ignorance there. That same person

original: apariyāpanne so tato kāmarāgānusayañca paṭighānusayañca nappajahati avijjānusayañca
analyzed: a pariyāpanne saḥ tatas kāma rāga anusayañca paṭigha anusayañca na ppajahati avijjā anusayañca
translated: in the unincluded does not abandon the underlying tendency to lust for sensual desires and the underlying tendency to aversion and the underlying tendency to ignorance.

original: nappajahati. Dvinnaṁ maggasamaṅgīnaṁ ṭhapetvā avasesā puggalā sabbattha kāmarāgānusayañca🔽paṭighānusayañca nappajahanti avijjānusayañca nappajahanti.
analyzed: na ppajahati dvinnam magga samaṅgīnam ṭhapetvā avasesā puggalā sabbattha kāma rāga anusayam ca  paṭigha anusayañca na ppajahanti avijjā anusayañca na ppajahanti
translated: Except for two persons possessing the path, the rest do not abandon the underlying tendency to lust for sensual desires and the underlying tendency to aversion and the underlying tendency to ignorance everywhere.

original: Yo vā pana yato avijjānusayaṁ nappajahati so tato kāmarāgānusayañca paṭighānusayañca nappajahatīti?
analyzed: yaḥ vā pana yatas avijjā anusayam na ppajahati saḥ tatas kāma rāga anusayam ca paṭigha anusayam ca na ppajahati iti
translated: Or, if anyone does not abandon the underlying tendency to ignorance in any given place, does he not also abandon the underlying tendency to lust for sensual desires and the underlying tendency to aversion there?

original: Anāgāmimaggasamaṅgī dukkhāya vedanāya so tato avijjānusayañca kāmarāgānusayañca nappajahati,
analyzed: anāgāmi magga samaṅgī dukkhāya vedanāya saḥ tatas avijjā anusayañca kāma rāga anusayañca na ppajahati
translated: One possessing the path of Non-Returner does not abandon the underlying tendency to ignorance and the underlying tendency to lust for sensual desires in painful feeling,

original: no ca so tato paṭighānusayaṁ nappajahati. Sveva puggalo kāmadhātuyā dvīsu vedanāsu
analyzed: no ca so tatas paṭigha anusayam na ppajahati su eva puggalaḥ kāmadhātuyā dvīsu vedanāsu
translated: but he does not not abandon the underlying tendency to aversion there. That same person in the sense-desire element in two kinds of feeling

original: so tato avijjānusayañca paṭighānusayañca nappajahati, no ca so tato kāmarāgānusayaṁ🔽nappajahati. Sveva puggalo rūpadhātuyā arūpadhātuyā apariyāpanne so tato avijjānusayañca
analyzed: so tato avijjā anusayañca paṭigha anusayañca na ppajahati no ca so tato kāma rāga anusaya  na ppajahati sveva puggalaḥ rūpa dhātuyā a rūpa dhātuyā a pariyāpanne saḥ tatas avijjā anusayam ca
translated: He does not abandon the underlying tendency to ignorance and the underlying tendency to resentment, but he does not abandon the underlying tendency to lust for sensual desires.

original: nappajahati kāmarāgānusayañca paṭighānusayañca nappajahati. Dvinnaṁ maggasamaṅgīnaṁ🔽ṭhapetvā avasesā puggalā sabbattha avijjānusayañca nappajahanti kāmarāgānusayañca
analyzed: na ppajahati kāma rāga anusayañca paṭigha anusayañca na ppajahati dvinnam  ṭhapetvā avasesā puggalā sabbattha avijjā anusayañca na ppajahanti kāma rāga anusayañca
translated: This person does not abandon the underlying tendency to ignorance and the underlying tendency to lust for sensual desires, but he does not abandon the underlying tendency to resentment.🔽Except for two persons who possess the path,

original: paṭighānusayañca nappajahanti. (Dukamūlakaṁ.)
analyzed: paṭigha anusayam ca na ppajahanti duka mūlaka
translated: all other persons do not abandon the underlying tendency to ignorance, the underlying tendency to lust for sensual desires, and the underlying tendency to resentment.🔽(The root text is to be expanded in the same way as for the three roots.)

original: Yo yato kāmarāgānusayañca paṭighānusayañca mānānusayañca nappajahati so tato diṭṭhānusayaṁ …pe… vicikicchānusayaṁ nappajahatīti?🔽Aṭṭhamako kāmadhātuyā tīsu vedanāsu rūpadhātuyā arūpadhātuyā so tato kāmarāgānusayañca
analyzed: yaḥ yatas kāma rāga anusayam ca paṭigha anusayam ca māna anusayam ca na ppajahati saḥ tatas diṭṭha anusayam pe vicikicchā anusayam na ppajahati iti  aṭṭhamako kāmadhātuyā tīsu vedanāsu rūpadhātuyā arūpadhātuyā so tato kāma rāga anusayaṃ ca
translated: Does anyone not abandon the underlying tendency to lust for sensual desires, the underlying tendency to resentment, and the underlying tendency to conceit in a certain instance without abandoning the underlying tendency to views in that instance?

original: paṭighānusayañca mānānusayañca nappajahati, no ca so tato vicikicchānusayaṁ nappajahati.
analyzed: paṭigha anusayam ca māna anusayam ca na ppajahati no ca so tatas vicikicchā anusayam na ppajahati
translated: The eighth person does not abandon the underlying tendency to lust for sensual desires, the underlying tendency to resentment, and the underlying tendency to conceit in the sense-desire element and in the three kinds of feeling in the form element and the formless element, but he does not abandon the underlying tendency to uncertainty.

original: Sveva puggalo apariyāpanne so tato kāmarāgānusayañca paṭighānusayañca mānānusayañca🔽nappajahati vicikicchānusayañca nappajahati. Dvinnaṁ maggasamaṅgīnañca aṭṭhamakañca🔽ṭhapetvā avasesā puggalā sabbattha kāmarāgānusayañca paṭighānusayañca mānānusayañca🔽nappajahanti vicikicchānusayañca nappajahanti.🔽Yo vā pana yato vicikicchānusayaṁ nappajahati so tato kāmarāgānusayañca paṭighānusayañca mānānusayañca nappajahatīti?🔽Anāgāmimaggasamaṅgī dukkhāya vedanāya so tato vicikicchānusayañca kāmarāgānusayañca
analyzed: su eva puggalaḥ apariyāpanne saḥ tatas kāma rāga anusayañca paṭigha anusayañca māna anusayañca  na ppajahati vicikicchā anusayañca na ppajahati dvinnam magga samaṅgīnam ca aṭṭhamakañca  ṭhapetvā avasesā puggalā sabbattha kāma rāga anusayañca paṭigha anusayañca māna anusayañca  na ppajahanti vicikicchā anusayam ca na ppajahanti  yaḥ vā pana yatas vicikicchā anusayam na ppajahati saḥ tatas kāma rāga anusayam ca paṭigha anusayam ca māna anusayam ca na ppajahati iti  anāgāmi magga samaṅgī dukkhāya vedanāya saḥ tatas vicikicchā anusayañca kāma rāga anusayañca
translated: That same person, in the immaterial sphere, does not abandon the underlying tendency to lust and the underlying tendency to conceit,

analyzed: māna anusayam ca na ppajahati no ca so tatas paṭigha anusayam na ppajahati su eva puggalo 🔽kāmadhātuyāḥ dvīsu vedanāsu saḥ tatas vicikicchā anusayañca paṭigha anusayañca māna anusayañca

original: nappajahati, no ca so tato kāmarāgānusayaṁ nappajahati. Sveva puggalo rūpadhātuyā
analyzed: na ppajahati no ca so tatas kāma rāga anusayam na ppajahati su eva puggalaḥ rūpadhātuyā

original: arūpadhātuyā apariyāpanne so tato vicikicchānusayañca nappajahati kāmarāgānusayañca
analyzed: arūpadhātuyāḥ apariyāpanne saḥ tatas vicikicchā anusayañca na ppajahati kāma rāga anusayañca

original: paṭighānusayañca mānānusayañca nappajahati. Aggamaggasamaṅgī kāmadhātuyā dvīsu vedanāsu
analyzed: paṭigha anusayañca māna anusayañca na ppajahati agga magga samaṅgī kāmadhātuyā dvīsu vedanāsu
translated: nor the underlying tendency to resentment there, nor the underlying tendency to conceit there. The person who is possessed of the path of stream-entry, in the sense-desire element and in two of the feelings

original: nappajahati, no ca so tato mānānusayaṁ nappajahati. Sveva puggalo dukkhāya vedanāya
analyzed: na ppajahati no ca so tatas māna anusayam na ppajahati su eva puggalaḥ dukkhāya vedanāya

original: apariyāpanne so tato vicikicchānusayañca nappajahati kāmarāgānusayañca paṭighānusayañca
analyzed: a pariyāpanne saḥ tatas vicikicchā anusayañca na ppajahati kāma rāga anusayañca paṭigha anusayañca
translated: in that which is not included in the three realms, he does not abandon the underlying tendency to uncertainty there, nor the underlying tendency to lust for sensual desires there, nor the underlying tendency to resentment there,

original: mānānusayañca nappajahati. Dvinnaṁ maggasamaṅgīnañca aṭṭhamakañca ṭhapetvā avasesā
analyzed: māna anusayañca na ppajahati dvinnam magga samaṅgīnam ca aṭṭhamakam ca ṭhapetvā avasesā
